Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I have completed this book for you, my Sons, which is the last in the science of medicine with its complement, and I have reached the end of it according to its exposition and declaration, it seemed to me that I should complete it with this Tractate, which is a part of the operation, namely surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Because the operation by hand has fallen into disuse in our region and time, so that perhaps its knowledge has perished and its trace has been cut off; and nothing of it remains except small descriptions in the books of the ancients, which hands have changed, and error and hesitation have befallen them until their intentions were closed and their power was distant. It seemed to me that I should revive this science with the arrangement of this Tractate in it according to the way of exposition, declaration, and abbreviation; and that I come with the forms of the tools of cautery and the other instruments of work: as is done by the addition of declarations and their hastening.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why a good artisan of it is not found with his hand in this our time is that the art of medicine is long, and its author must be trained beforehand in the science of anatomy, as Galen has narrated, until he knows the supports of the limbs and their forms, and their conjunction and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and sinews, and their number, and their exit, and the pulsatile and quiet veins, and the places of their exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And because of that, Hippocrates said: "The name with the name is much, and with work it is little, especially in the art of hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 But we have already spoken about this at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	 "For one who is not skilled in anatomy may fall into error, by which people are killed: as I have seen many of those who boast about this skill without knowledge or experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 "That is, because I saw a foolish physician cut out a scrofulous abscess on a woman's neck and he cut some of the arteries in the neck; therefore the blood flowed from the woman until she died in his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 "And I saw another physician who dared to remove a stone from a man who had grown old, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 "So he came to him and removed it with a piece of the bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 "Therefore the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 "And indeed I had already been called to remove it; and seeing the size of the stone and the condition of the patient, I knew that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 "And I saw another physician who was receiving a fee from a certain Duke of our land for his medical skill; and it happened that the Duke's black eunuch had a fracture in his leg near the heel: and the physician hastened with his ignorance, and bound up the fracture on the wound with bandages and tight cords, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 "Then he released him according to his wishes.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 "After a few days he dismissed him and instructed him not to loosen the bandage; and it remained so until his leg became swollen, as well as his foot, and it came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 "So I was called to him; and I hastened to loosen the bandage; and he was restored to peace, and escaped from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 "However, the corruption had already set in the limb; and I could not prevent it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Thus, when the corruption ceased wandering through the limb, until it died.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 And I saw another physician, who punctured a cancerous abscess: and after some days it ulcerated, until its evil grew great with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 That is, because when it is a pure cancer of black bile, then one must not approach it with iron at all, unless it is in a member that can endure it, so that the whole of it may be cut out.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And for this reason, O Sons, it is necessary for you to know that the operation with the hand is divided into two divisions: namely, the operation which is associated with health, and the operation with which there is danger in many cases.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already pointed out in every place of this book where the operation comes which has terror and fear.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of that and abandon it, so that the foolish may not find a way to speak and dishonor it.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Receive therefore the measure with diligence and care, and your weak ones with ease and strength, and use the better way leading by God's grace to health and praiseworthy success: and put away terrible diseases that are difficult to cure: and lift up your spirits from that which makes you afraid, so that hesitation may not enter upon you in your faith and advantage. xspace
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it is more lasting to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your quantities.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 For Galen has already said this in some of his warnings.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat the disease badly, lest you be called bad physicians.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now, however, I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	 Chapter One
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 Of the Cautery with fire, and of the Cautery with sharp medicine, arranged and ordered from the head to the feet, and with forms of instruments and tools of the Cautery: and everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	 Chapter Two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 On incisions and punctures, bloodletting and cupping, wounds, and the extraction of arrows and similar things; all arranged according to the shapes of the instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	 Chapter Three.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 On the restoration of dislocations and the treatment of twists, and similar things; arranged by parts from head to foot and according to the shapes of the instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Book of Surgery by Al-Zahrawi.
Pars I.	 Part I
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 On the benefit and harm of cautery; in which constitutions it is beneficial, and at what times; whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	 Chapter One
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 But before remembering the use of cautery, it is necessary to say what its beneficial and harmful qualities are, and in which constitution it should be used.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 I say therefore that the discourse on the quality of the benefit and harm of cautery is a lengthy, subtle, scientific, and hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 Many wise men have spoken about it and differed on the subject, and for me a little of their speech is enough, fearing lengthiness. ︎
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 I say therefore that cautery is beneficial to every constitution, whether material or immaterial, except for two constitutions: a hot constitution without matter and a dry constitution without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 But in a hot and dry constitution with matter they differed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 For some have said that cautery is beneficial in it.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others said the opposite, that is, that cautery is not suitable for an illness caused by heat and dryness; since the nature of fire is heat, and it is inappropriate to heal a hot and dry illness with what is hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And the one who speaks against that says: that by cautery there is a benefit in every hot and dry disease which occurs in human bodies; because when you compare the human body and its humors to the nature of fire, you find the human body cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I say through his statement: because experience has revealed this to me many times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 However, it is not necessary that this be attempted except by one who has already been tested and practiced in the last exercise of cautery, and knows the diversity of human complexions, and the nature of diseases within them, and their causes, and their symptoms, and the duration of time for them.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 From the other complexions there is no need to fear, especially in cold and moist diseases.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 For all doctors have agreed upon them; and they have not disagreed about the benefit of cautery in those cases.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, my sons, that the secret of treatment by cautery with fire and its goodness is superior to cautery with burning medicine, because fire is simple, whose action does not extend except to the member which is cauterized; and it does not harm another connected member, unless with slight harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 But the action of burning medicine extends to what is distant from the members; and perhaps it brings about disease in the member which is difficult to heal, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 But fire, because of its subtlety and the goodness of its substance, does not do this except in excess.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 Indeed, we have learned this through experience because of the length of our service and study with art, and our commitment to the truth of things; and for that reason I am excused from further discourse.  />  />
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it were not so, because it is not permitted to this book of mine, I would bring you the hidden secret in fire, and the quality of its operation in expelling humors from the body, demonstrated with philosophical discourse which would be understood by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, my sons, that they disagree about the time when it is suitable to perform cautery, and they consider spring to be a better time.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that cautery is suitable at any time; for the harm caused by the time will be overwhelmed by the benefit derived from cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if cautery is necessary because of severe and persistent pains that do not tolerate delay; for fear that from them something worse may occur than the slight harm caused by the time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	 And let it not enter your minds, my sons, that only the common and foolish physicians think so; namely, that the disease which is cured by cautery does not always return: and they put forward this consequence, but it is not as they think; because cautery is only in the place of medicine, which alters the complexion and dries up the humors which are the causes of pains.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 Nevertheless, cautery excels medicine in the swiftness of its effect, and the power of its action, and the strength of its dominion: and it is possible for the disease to return at some time according to the complexion of the patient, and the location of his disease, and its power; and what has been prepared in his body through the accumulation of superfluous humors in him; and what reaches him from his food and similar causes, unless the disease is one in which cautery is applied.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 A slight disease of a member with few superfluous humors and moisture, such as tooth cautery for pain, and similar conditions, it is possible that this pain will not return.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 But this happens rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 But the common saying that cautery is the last resort of medicine is true; not in the sense they intend by it; for they believe that there is no cure which is as effective as medicine or any other treatment after cautery has been applied. (){#}
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 "The truth of the matter is contrary to this, and the intent is that cautery is the last resort in medicine; it is not used unless when we apply methods of healing for some ailments, those remedies do not work. Then at the end, we apply cautery, and it helps. Therefore, it follows that cautery is the last resort in medicine, not according to the intention that the common people and most ignorant physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 "The ancients said that cautery with gold is better than cautery with iron; and they did not say this except because of the equality of gold and the nobility of its substance. They also said that the site of the cautery does not become inflamed.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 "In truth, this is not absolutely the case; for I have already tested it and found that, in some bodies, it does so without any other cause.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 "And cautery with gold is good and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 "However, when you use a cautery made of gold in the fire, it does not indicate to you when it has reached the desired heat because of the redness of the gold; and if it cools down too quickly, and if you add more fire, it melts in the flame and turns into layers.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 "For this reason, the craftsman falls into difficulty with it; and for this reason, cautery made of iron is quicker and more convenient for us, being suitable for the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 "And I have already arranged this chapter on the cautery according to chapters, and I have arranged them from head to foot, so that they may provide relief for those seeking something from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 "About the Method of Cauterizing the Head in the Coronal Suture.
Caput II.	 "Chapter Two
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 "This cauterization is beneficial for controlling moisture and coldness over the brain, which are two causes of headaches, excessive flow of humors to the eyes and ears, too much sleep, toothache, throat pain, and universally all ailments that occur from coldness, such as paralysis, headaches, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar diseases.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is as follows: first instruct the patient to evacuate with a cleansing purgative for three or four nights, according to the strength of the patient, their age, and their habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then have him sit facing you, with his hands placed on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then place the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Wherever your middle finger reaches, mark that spot with ink.  />  And do this three times in succession.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then prepare the cautery iron for the fire: its form is as follows.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then place it on the marked spot with ink, gradually tightening your hand as you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Then quickly lift your hand and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that the bone has been exposed to the size of a lentil or a grain of barley, then lift your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, repeat with the same iron or another one if this one has cooled down: until you see the bones I mentioned to you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take some salt, dissolve it in water, soak a cloth in it, and place it on the spot: and leave it there for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place a cloth soaked in butter over it, and leave it on the spot until the scar of the fire is destroyed.  />
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with four-ingredient ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 They say that the more open the wound remains, the more pus is released, which is better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 And some say that the skin should be cauterized all the way to the bone, and that the cautery should be held until something of the thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then it is scraped from the burned area of the bone, then it is cleaned.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 And others say that one should use the cautery until it reaches the end, so that it makes an impression on the bone in the shape of a circle: or they use a small instrument that women place into infusions of alphabet letters; and they believe that the vapors of the head are expelled from this location, and the wound should be left open for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then it should be cleaned until it heals.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 But these two types of cautery seem to me not at all except in some people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And leaving it is better for me with his health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 The head is weakened by the dissolution of its natural continuity, as we have testified with other members; and especially when the head is naturally weak due to illness. The first type of cautery, however, is safer and better for me, and I use it. Therefore, operate with it in safety.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 About how to cauterize the head when the whole head hurts.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When a chronic and persistent pain occurs in the whole head of the patient, and he makes use of hyeres (a type of poultice), coches (ointments or unguents), head purges, oils, and emplastrums (medicated plasters).
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And especially if it has already been cauterized with the one-pronged cautery that we have described, and none of those things help him, then consider this.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 For if the patient's head is of a strong natural constitution and not weak, and he finds severe cold, then cauterize him with another cautery under that one, in a small amount.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize him over every horn of his head with the cautery, so that it does not penetrate through the skin, and expose a quantity from the bone as we have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 And burn it with one cautery on the back of his head, in the place called vas: and lift up your hand in this manner, and do not expose the mouth.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 For the patient will find on account of this a very severe pain, and different from the pain of all other head cauteries.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I call this cautery the one for its place: and it should be a cautery that is finer than the one used to cauterize the horns of the head and its back.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 § On how to cauterize for migraine, both with a burning drug and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter Four
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When pain occurs on one side of the head or extends to the eye and is evacuated with purgative drugs, and the remaining treatment as I mentioned in the divisions of diseases is not effective, then cautery for this condition is according to two methods: either cautery with a burning, acute drug; or with iron. 》
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 The cautery with a burning, acute drug is as follows: take one tooth of garlic and peel it, and cut off the tips from both sides of it.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then split the painful place in time with a wide fleam until there is made under the skin a space in which to insert the tooth.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Insert it under the skin until it is hidden; then tie over it with a suitable bandage; and leave it for fifteen hours; then untie it, and extract the garlic, and let the wound be left open for two days, or three; then place on it cotton soaked in butter until the place produces pus; then treat it with ointment until it is healed. 》
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to do this with some burning drugs that I have written about in the twelfth treatise, on Burning Medicines.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 The cauterization of it with iron is done in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 A cautery of fire, the form of which is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 And it is called a nail-shaped cautery because the form of its head is like that of a nail, in which there is something of curvature, and in the middle of it is a small projection.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the spot and hold your hand steady; and you revolve the iron little by little with speed; and let the quantity that is burned be from the thickness of the skin, as its half.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And lift your hand so that the artery below is not burned and a flow of blood occurs.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then soak a piece of cotton in salt water and place it on the spot and leave it for three days; then place the cotton with butter; afterwards treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this half of the skull with the tip of a small knife similar to the cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 And beware of cutting an artery in this half of the skull, not properly ancient.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 § On the manner of cauterizing in the old half of the skull.
Caput V.	 Chapter Five
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When you treat the half of the skull with what we have said in the previous treatment and what we have said in the divisions of diseases, and the treatment does not help; and you see from the disease that what we have said from the first cautery with medicine or with the cautery with fire is not enough for it, then you must heat a knife-shaped cautery until it turns white after you mark on the spot of pain with a line whose length is half a finger, or almost like that; and lift your hand once, and press it until you cut the artery and reach the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 Nevertheless, it is necessary for you to beware of the continuation of the jawbone that moves during chewing, lest the side or the nerve that moves it be burned and a spasm occur.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 "And let it be over a cover, as a precaution against bleeding from the cut artery.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 "For its incision is fearsome, especially for one who does not know what he is doing and is neither diligent nor experienced; and he abandons the operation first of all.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 "And I will discuss the regulation of bleeding from an artery according to its manner and in the appropriate place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 "But if you see from the illness that this cautery is not enough, and you see the patient's body enduring the cautery on the middle of the head, as we have described, take care of the wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 "And if you wish, administer the cautery that we mentioned in the chapter on extracting an artery with a double-bladed cautery.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 "For cauterization is better and more beneficial this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 "On the method of cauterizing for ear pain.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 "When ear pain occurs from cold and is treated with dissolving remedies and the other treatments we mentioned in the division, and the pain does not go away, then apply fire cautery. And this is what is called a 'punch,' which has this shape.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 "Then apply the punch after its burning around the entire ear, as it is shown; or around both ears if the pain is simultaneous in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 "And keep the cautery away from the root of the ear for a short while after marking the spots with wax; and let the number of punctures be ten on each ear, as shown.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 "Then care for the spots until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 "On the method of cauterizing for toothache.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 "The toothache that is treated with cauterization is only from the types that occur from phlegm, as we said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And avoid cauterization for conditions caused by dryness and nerve spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When you treat this type of pain with herbs, and head washes, and gargles, and your treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you cauterize the patient with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, a second a little lower than its tympanum, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your cautery on the opposite side from the afflicted area.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Because softening occurs only in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the method of cauterization is that you cauterize with a cautery directly on the upper edge of the ear, a little below the horn of the head; and another in the tympanum, whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 And place your hand with the cautery until the thickness of half the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 And this is the form of the cautery, and it is a species made from a knife, whose form has been described; however, it is not somewhat thinner than that which you see, and it must be a knife with a little excess thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then treat the places with what has been mentioned until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for an old stroke.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When the stroke has become old, and you treat it with what we have mentioned, and your treatment does not help, and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every horn of his head, and a cautery in the middle of the head as we have said, and a cautery in the back of the head, according to what has been described: and the method of cauterization is according to what has been described. 》
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 And also cauterize with a cautery on the mouth of the stomach; and this is the most important [cautery]. 》
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then it should be scraped with what precedes it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for forgetfulness.
Caput IX.	 Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that first of all, large doses of horehound and pills cleansing the brain be given to the patient to drink.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then shave the whole head of the patient and place upon his occiput a plaster made of mustard, as described in the treatise on plasters; and repeat this several times.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For this is the method of cautery, and perform it in the same way as I mentioned there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If therefore he is cured by this, that is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not, then make three cauteries on the back of his head, which should descend from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye; and place between each cautery a thickness like that of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then treat the cauteries with what preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 But if you wish to add to it and the patient can tolerate it, then make a cautery in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 If you wish to add (to it), then cauterize him on both temples.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then treat (the patient) until he is cured; and let the cautery be anointed with oil according to the aforesaid form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for paralysis and flaccidity.
Caput X.	 Chapter 10. ︎
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 It is necessary that you proceed with the cleansing of the head using horehound and as we have said. ︎
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then shave the head of the patient; afterwards cauterize him with a cautery in the middle of his head and a cautery on each temple, and a cautery on the back of his head, and three cauteries on the nape of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 But if you need (to do) many things in the illness of flaccidity of the body, and the patient can tolerate it, and the illness is strong, then cauterize him with four cauteries on the nape of his back, and the last one until it burns most of his skin, and lift your hand. ︎ 
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then care for him until he is healed: and thus apply the cautery oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 On the Method of Cauterizing for Epilepsy
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 An epileptic is not cauterized unless his epilepsy is due to phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, you should first cleanse his brain with hyeros and with the other treatment that we have mentioned in the division, when the patient is large or is able to take medicines.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 But if he is a child who does not tolerate medicines, then give him a gargle and cleansing foods to chew for many days before that with the improvement of his food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then shave his head, afterward cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of his head, as has been mentioned before in the manner: and with another cautery on his nape, and on each horn of his head with a cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 If the patient is strong and tolerates it, then cauterize him with the cauteries that I have mentioned for one who has paralysis, and apply softening to his body over the vertebrae of the neck and the vertebrae of the back; and let the cautery oil be according to the manner that has been mentioned.  />
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 But if the patient is a child, then place a subtle cautery, in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing for Melancholy
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy is foul moisture and thick phlegm, then cauterize him with the cauteries that we have mentioned for one who has paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is an excess flowing down to the melancholy, and his body is moist, then give him in drink what cleanses his brain, as has been mentioned before in the division: then shave the head of the patient, and make afterward a nicely made ring from linen, like a circle.  />
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it on top of the head; and let the patient, seated on a stool, be held firmly from every side.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 And it is better made with ancient goose fat.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat the ointment over a moderate fire to the degree that a finger can bear when inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it onto the middle of his head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this for the patient once every week, along with the rest of his good diet, until he is healed.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small points on it, except that you should hold the hand with the cautery; indeed, it should be smelling.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with its quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then place upon it a compress soaked in butter or chicken fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing with descending water to the eye.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When the beginning of water in the eye is declared to you through the signs which I mentioned in the division, then begin and give the patient to drink along with something that will cleanse his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him away from all moisture and make him sit in a bath while fasting for some days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then instruct him to shave his head, and cauterize him on the middle of his head. 》
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then cauterize him over both temples with two cauteries, if the descent of water begins in both eyes at once; or on one side, if it begins in only one eye: and cut off all the veins and arteries which are under the skin with the cautery; and let the cauteries be long in the width of the temples; and beware of bleeding. 》
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see anything from it, then cut him off immediately with whatever medicine is possible; and I will come with the wisdom that is in extracting the arteries, and cutting them off, and being careful of bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes it is cauterized in the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries completely extended.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 On the way of cauterizing the old tears.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are old and constant, and they are on the veins and arteries which are externally visible on the forehead, it is verified that this is from cold and phlegmatic excesses; then cauterize with the same cautery as I narrated in the beginning for descending water, one cautery in the middle of the forehead, and two cauteries above the temples, and two cauteries in the neck under the bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if you need an addition, then cauterize it on every side of the eye, above the outer edge of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 On the way of cauterizing nose stench.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you treat it with what we said in the section on division and the treatment is not beneficial, then hurry and give infirmocochias to drink for three nights; afterwards shave his head and cauterize him with a medium cautery, and with an olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then cauterize him with two nail-shaped cauteries on the outer edges of the eyebrows under a few hairs.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And be careful not to cut into the artery.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the shape of the nail-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 On the way of cauterizing for softening the eyelid. ‌
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of the eye is softened from illness or moisture, then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, and this lunar-shaped cautery. ‌
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it a little on the outer edges of both eyebrows with two cauteries all around; and let them be distant from the temples; and let the length of every cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow; and do not bring your hand to an end with the cautery, rather according to the amount that is burnt on the third eyelid. ‌
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the form of the caustic according to this method of the lunar caustic.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 About the way of cauterizing the eyelid when the hair turns back and pricks the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 The caustic in it is according to two methods: either the caustic with fire, or the caustic with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 But in the caustic with fire, first instruct the patient to let their hairs grow out, if they are among those who pluck them, until they lengthen and even out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 But if they prick him at their growth, then bind his eyes with a ribbon so that they do not move until they are born.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 Therefore, when they are born and even out, then place the patient's head in your lap; then mark on his eyelids with encaustic, a mark like the shape of a myrtle leaf, and let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then place a cotton soaked in egg white or in the mucilage of fleawort over the eye. ¶ Et sic cauterizabis eum, et sanabitur.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then the caustic with fire, whose shape is this:
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize over the shape that you have marked little by little in many times, until the skin surface, which is like the shape of a myrtle leaf, becomes completely evident.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And the sign of health of your work is: if you see the eyelid of the eye already contracting and the hairs lifting from the pricking point of the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then lift your hand; and leave him for three days. ¶ Deinde adiungas ei, in uino cum zibado, puluerem aloes de quattuor partibus, et mellis de uno: et mitte illum per nares.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then place a cotton with butter on it, until the scab is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with ointment, until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If any hair grows back after an hour and the eyelid softens, then repeat the cautery on that spot as you did first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 But if the hairs are on the lower (eyelid), then cauterize it until it is raised to its natural place, and it is even so that the hairs do not prick the eye.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 About how to cauterize with a burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 It is that you instruct the patient to let the hairs grow until they are lengthened and evened out.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make from linen cloth the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take from known soap and from unmixed lime a weight of one ounce or about that amount from each; then grind them together well until they become like this quickly, so that it does not cool down.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then spread the paste from this onto the linen cloth you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it on the eyelid of one or two eyes. ︎
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 And place under the eye a compress soaked in egg white, and let the patient's head rest on your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 And place your index finger on the medicine, and press it briefly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 And you move it whenever the patient feels the burning of the medicine, for its burning is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While this persists, which the patient finds to be a burning sensation, then remove the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When the burning sensation has subsided, then remove the medicine, and wash the eye with water. ︎ ︎
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 And then consider if you see the eyelid being raised, as it is raised by contracting with fire or with incision; that is good. And if not, then repeat the medicine on the same spot where the medicine does not imprint and does not darken, until your work becomes even and the eye contracts. ︎ ︎ ︎
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place on it the kohl with butter until the skin of the burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with diaphoretic ointment or another until it heals.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 And it is necessary for you during the treatment that you guard with the highest care lest anything from the medicine fall into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 And if the eyelid softens after some days and something from the hairs enters into the eye, then repeat the medicine on that place which becomes softened from the eyelid as you did at first.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the form of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that the eyes of men differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore let your consideration be according to this, and the way of righteousness shall not be hidden from him who is dedicated to this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing the Tear Duct.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you treat the fistula with what we have said in the divisions of diseases and your treatment does not succeed: then it is necessary for you to cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Instruct the patient to place his head in your lap, and let an assistant hold his head between his hands so that it does not move or shake with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then place kohl mixed in the white of an egg or in slippery elm mucilage on his eye; then with a cautery iron, whose form is this. ➤
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 Let it be hollow like the form of a vulture feather from one end, with which is made the cautery; and if its strength is to penetrate to the other end, and if its strength is upward thus do you try.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 However, this hollow (one) is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then express the fistula if it is open, and draw out its pus, and dry it; and if it is not open, then open it, and draw out its pus. ➤
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place a hot cautery on it.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold the cautery with your hand near the eye and towards the nose, so that your hand does not wander or disturb the patient; and place the cautery on the eye fat and burn it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If you reach the beginning of the vein all the way to the mouth, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery once or twice, if you need it; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then put a compress with butter on it, and care for him with a drying ointment until he is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 But if forty days have passed and he is not healed, then place a sharp corrosive medicine on it until the mouth is uncovered; and scrape it according to its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another method of cautery for a fistula, which some have said first.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Find the place of the fistula and locate it; then put a thin camahan, that is, a thin cannula, whose form is this. ➤
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 And pour into it the quantity of a drachm of molten lead, and hold your hand with the canula firmly, so that the patient is not moved at all, lest the molten lead run or reach his eye. ➤
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And it is necessary to put a compress soaked in egg white or water on the patient's eye.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For molten lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it with a wonderful healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 But if the fistula is healed with what we have said about cautery and treatment, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 And if not, then it is necessary to enlarge the nasal passage and redirect the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what will come to its own proper place. ➤ ➤
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 To Cauterize Fissures of the Lips
Caput XX.	 Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Often there are fissures on the lips, which are called "hairs," and especially on the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 Therefore, when you are treating these fissures with what we said about the division of diseases, and it does not help, then prepare a small cautery blade like this one.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its concavity be according to the sharpness of the blade.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then quickly place the heated one on these fissures until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissure.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with cerate until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 To Cauterize a Fistula of the Mouth
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or on the palate, or at the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts: after that it becomes chronic and runs with pus, and a fistula forms: then you treat it, and it does not help in that case, then you must heat the cautery according to the size that fits into the fistula. ething is that if there is a fissure on the lip of a child, you should be careful not to burn too much of the surrounding flesh, because the child's flesh is soft and tender and easily burns.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then insert the heated one into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand until the heated iron reaches its depth and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then treat it afterwards with what we said about treatment until it heals. ething is that if there is a fissure on the lip of a child, you should be careful not to burn too much of the surrounding flesh, because the child's flesh is soft and tender and easily burns.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If the pus drains away and it heals, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to expose the place and remove the necrotic flesh according to what will be said in its chapter.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 "On the Method of Cauterizing Soft Gums and Teeth
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gums are softened due to moisture and the teeth are loose, and after treating them with medicines they do not improve, then place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then, take a cautery tool whose form will be described later, and place the cannula over the tooth. Quickly introduce the burning cautery into it, and hold your hand for a moment until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 And lift your hand; then repeat the cautery several times according to your will.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then the patient should fill his mouth with salt water and hold it for an hour, then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 For a loose tooth is made firm, a softened gum is tightened, and the corrupted moisture is dried.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 "On the Method of Cauterizing for Toothache
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter 23
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When toothache is caused by coldness, whether the cold is within the tooth itself or in a worm, and treatment with medicines does not help, then there are two ways to apply cautery to it: either cautery with butter or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 The method of cautery with butter is as follows: take fresh cow's butter and boil it in an iron ladle or a bronze bowl.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then take a piece of cotton and wrap it around the end of a probe. 》
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Then dip the cotton in the boiled butter and quickly place it on the aching tooth, holding it until it cools down; then repeat this several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 And if you wish, dip wool or cotton in cold butter and place it on the aching tooth; then place a burning iron on it until the fire reaches the depth of the tooth's cavity.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 "The cauterization of it with fire is performed by placing a tube of air or a tube of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 "And there should be something thick in the body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not reach the mouth of the wound.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 "Then take a cautery of fire and place it on that tooth until the cautery cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 "Do this several times, for the pain will be removed either on that same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 "And it is necessary for the patient to fill his mouth with good butter and hold it for one hour; then he should spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 "And this is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 "Cauterize with whatever sharp end is possible; and this is the shape of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 "On the method of cauterizing in cases of thrush.
Caput XXIIII.	 "Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 "When thrush is caused by phlegm and cold moisture and does not respond to treatment with medicines, and you wish to quickly hasten their digestion; then take a hollow cautery of fire, the shape of which is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 "Having two open ends, so that the smoke may escape from one end; and place it ignited on the swelling once or twice if needed, until it reaches the depth of the swelling.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 "But if the swelling is small, then place the cautery according to the size of the swelling.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 "Then leave it for three days, and place a piece of cotton soaked in butter on it until what the fire has burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 "Then treat it with tooth salve until it heals to the shape of a tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 "On the method of cauterizing hoarseness and constriction of breath.
Caput XXV.	 "Chapter 25.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When moistness overcomes the bronchial tube, especially when it is with cold disposition, then the sick person should be first evacuated with purgative medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then burn the patient on the neck at the root of the throat in a depressed place; and be careful not to reach the throat with the cautery, nor the skin, except for something of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then burn the patient with another cautery at the neck joint in the last vertebra of the collarbone; and let the cautery be small according to the previously mentioned method.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then treat the patient with what has been mentioned until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 On how to burn in lung diseases and coughs.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	 When cough and lung disease are from cold moistness, and the patient has no fever or phthisis (consumption), and the disease is not chronic, then burn the patient with two cauteries above the collarbone in depressed, mild, empty places.
