Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	 And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two breasts; and let the cautery be like a reed according to the previous method.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	 And if you wish to burn by pricking with a cautery called the Point, whose shape has been mentioned for pricking ear pain; and let the pricks be up to thirty in number, almost to the others.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with what has been mentioned until he is cured.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	 And now let the cautery have three branches: according to this shape.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	 Why is the burning alleviated when you do with it in one application the work of three cauteries? >()
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	 On how to burn in itchiness and shoulder dislocation.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	 When the head is dislocated because of humors and does not reset within an hour after its dislocation, until it becomes habitual for it to return, then it should be reduced from a slight movement that occurs as we have already testified about that; then you should reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	 Then the patient is turned onto their back, or onto their healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	 Then lift up the skin which is on the inner part of the thigh with your left hand fingers and if the joint is dislocated towards the inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	 Then take a cautery with two prongs.
Cuius forma est haec.	 Whose form is this:
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	 Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates through to the other side, and a figure of four cauteries will appear.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	 And sometimes the cautery is done with a three-pronged cautery, which results in a figure of six cauteries; and these prongs are according to the fineness of the thread.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	 And this is the form of the three-pronged cautery.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	 And sometimes an additional one is added to this method, making eight cauteries in total.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	 Then place crushed garlic mixed with salt on the cautery.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	 Then make the patient lie still so that the limb is not moved at any time until it becomes stronger.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	 And if the dislocation is towards the upper part, which rarely happens, then cauterize it on the shoulder with a nail-shaped cautery or by making multiple punctures with many cauteries.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	 For the joint is strengthened and the moisture is removed, and the patient is healed.  />
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter 28
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	 When cold and excessive moisture affect the stomach, to the point of drawing it away from its natural temperament, and produce catarrh in it, and when the repeated methods of treatment prove ineffective, then the patient must be turned onto their back, extending their legs and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	 Then cauterize with three cauteries: a shell-shaped cautery the size of one finger joint on the chest, along with a nail-shaped cautery, and two more cauteries below, one on each side of the first cautery, until a triangular figure appears.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	 And extend between both so that they do not join when making pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	 And the depth of the cautery should be two-thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	 And let the figure of the cauteries be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let the cautery by which this is done be one, according to the form of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	 And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it with this cautery: and it is as if you mark on the stomach a point according to the quantity that you wish with encaustic: then cauterize it with the point cautery; then treat it with the treatment mentioned until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing cold spleen.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	 When pain occurs in the spleen from cold and moisture, or from excessive flatulence, until it excretes its superfluous excretion according to its natural constitution, and the patient is treated with what we have said, but does not improve: then it is necessary that the patient be turned onto their back, and mark three cauteries with encaustic in this form and size below the hypochondrium, where the arm reaches: and let the space between each cautery be according to the thickness of a finger; and let the cautery be straight according to the length of the body. And do not press too hard with your hand on the cautery.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	 And let the quantity that is burned be half the thickness of the skin, without addition: and let the patient stand on their feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	 If, however, the patient is unable to stand, then let them lie down with their legs extended and their arms raised.
Haec est forma cauterii.	 This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	 And you may indeed be able to cauterize this cautery with a scalpel cautery when you have skill and knowledge in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	 And beware not to proceed too far in cauterization, so that the thickness of the whole skin is burned, which burns the whole body and reaches the intestines; for there the skin is thin, know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	 On the method of cauterizing liver abscesses.
Caput XXX.	 Chapter XXX.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	 When the abscess bursts and you want to know whether it is in the flesh of the liver or its membrane, then if it is in the flesh of the liver, a pain and weight without sharpness comes upon the patient; but if it is in the membrane of the liver, along with the pain there is severe sharpness. And you see that his physicians have been tired out by his treatment.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	 Therefore, the patient should lie on his back.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 Then mark the site of the abscess with a cautery; then heat the cautery which resembles a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	 And burn with it once until the whole skin is burned and reaches the abscess, until all the pus comes out; then treat him with the treatment of bursts until he heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	 And it is not appropriate for someone to use this kind of cautery unless his study in the art of medicine has been prolonged and through whose hands these diseases have often passed with experience; then indeed he may dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	 But to leave it alone is better in my opinion.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	 The ancients said: for cold pleurisy, use a cautery with the roots of Aristolochia in this manner. eben
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	 And it is done by taking from the dried roots of Aristolochia a root longer than the others that can be found there, and let its thickness be like that of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	 Then immerse it in oil and light it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	 Then cauterize with one cautery between the continuation of the furcula and the neck, and with two small cauteries slanting downwards towards that which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	 And with two more cauteries slanting downwards towards the back between the fifth and sixth ribs; and one cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	 And three more cauteries from behind: one between the two scapulae; and two below that cautery which is between the two scapulae.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	 And it is not necessary to press the hand with the cautery, but rather let it be in plain sight, giving off its scent on the skin.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	 And some ancient authorities have said that there are men who use a cautery of iron like a needle, and they heat it and insert it between the ribs until it reaches the abscess, and pus comes out, as we have said concerning the hepatic abscess.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	 But in this perforation with the cautery there is fear that either the patient dies immediately, or a fistula results which cannot be healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	 § On Cauterizing the Spleen Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	 When you are treating an illness of the spleen, according to what we have said about the division of diseases and your treatment is not effective, then there are three ways to cauterize it, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	 The first is to make three or four cauteries in a line along the length of the spleen, following the shape of the liver cauteries whose figure we have described earlier.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	 And between each cautery there should be the thickness of a finger or a little more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	 And the method of cauterizing should be as we have described for the liver cautery, equally so.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	 And do not press down with the cautery, and let the patient be lying on their back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	 And another method of cauterization is as follows: Heat the cautery that has two prongs, which we have mentioned in the chapter on dislocation of the arm; and raise the skin that lies directly over the spleen, where the patient's left elbow reaches; and let your raising of the skin be according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall along the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	 Then introduce the two red-hot prongs until you pierce through the skin from the other side; then withdraw the cautery. Thus, four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	 And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery that has three prongs.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	 Then take care of the cautery after you have released it to discharge pus for many days, for it is more beneficial than any other previous treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	 On the Method of Cauterizing for Hydrops.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	 The cautery does not work in hydrops except when used on the affected area itself. />
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	 When you treat a hydroptic patient with the treatment methods mentioned in the division, and the treatment does not take effect, then it is necessary to cauterize him four times around the navel, and once on the stomach, and once on the liver, and once on the spleen, and twice on the back between the shoulders, and one directly over the chest, and another directly over the stomach. And let the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.  />
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	 Then leave the cautery open so that it may discharge pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	 And do not evacuate the patient from treatment after the cautery, for two benefits are added to him: and healing will hasten to him with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	 The form of the caustic used to burn the stomach should be like a key; and that used for burning the back should be like an olive leaf, as described above.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	 On the method of cauterizing the feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XLIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	 When they become swollen in a dropsical patient and fill with yellowish water, you should cauterize above the sole of the foot, which is between the auricular and annular bones; and lift up your hand with the caustic, and do not twist it; then lift up your hand, and do not press it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	 For the yellowish water will ooze out, and let the caustic be of this shape.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	 Then make two caustics on each of the two legs, and let the caustic be with a knife-shaped tip; and let the caustic be as long as the leg, one below the knee and the other lower than that, about halfway down the leg. And make two caustics on each hip. And leave the caustic open without treatment for a long time, so that some water may ooze out from it; then treat it along with the others we have mentioned.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	 On the method of cauterizing to relieve abdominal pain.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	 When there is abdominal pain due to cold and moisture, which weakens the retentive and digestive powers in the stomach and intestines; and it is treated with remedies but does not heal; and you see that the patient can tolerate a strong caustic, then cauterize him strongly on his stomach, as described before for the method of cauterizing the stomach with a circular caustic, and four subtle caustics around the navel, with a subtle key-shaped caustic; and a large caustic over the groin above the testicles, or two caustics. 
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	 And if you see abundant moisture and the patient tolerates it, then cauterize with a hot iron over the comb and a hot iron over each eye; and perhaps add two small cauteries near the great vein.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	 For indeed is a treatment that is successful, whose benefit does not go astray.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing Hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	 When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or just one, from thick, cold humors, or corrupt humidity, and they are treated as we have said in division, but no cure is effective; then cauterize with three hot irons on the lower back of the spine under the almieda briefly in a triangular shape, and with one hot iron under the navel about two finger-widths.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 And if you think that his stomach is chilled and he cannot digest food, and you see his face swollen; then cauterize him with a large hot iron on the stomach as before, and with one on his liver, another on his spleen, together with a clavicle cautery. Leave the cautery open for some time, then treat him until he is cured.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	 ¶ On the Method of Cauterizing the Anus After Their Excision.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	 When you cut out a hemorrhoid, then heat a hot iron that resembles a ray.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	 Then insert the glowing iron into the cut hemorrhoid, and with your hand press until the hot iron reaches the opening of the vein from which the blood flows; do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	 If therefore the hemorrhoids are many, then cauterize each one with a hot iron as we have narrated. xspace
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	 Then treat them with that which is beneficial for them from the ointments until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	 And if you cauterize him with a large cautery over the cataract, it is more effective for treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	 On the method of cauterizing an anal fistula.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	 When the patient does not comply with the incision and operation that we have described in its place, and is terrified by it, perhaps he will be cured with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	 Therefore, when someone has an anal fistula and it becomes chronic, pus runs from it, along with corrupting moisture.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	 It is more appropriate, therefore, to probe it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	 Then recognize its depth with the probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	 Then heat the cautery, which is similar to a ray [of light].
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	 Then introduce the heated cautery into the fistula itself and the amount of depth that the probe entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 And repeat the cautery on it until all those corrupt bodies are burnt away, once, or twice, or three times, according to your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	 And beware of burning the nerve, if it is there, or a large vein; or if the fistula extends to the bladder body, or the intestine body, then beware of all these places. ︎
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	 And do not do this unless the fistula is in a fleshy place; and know that it does not penetrate deeply.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	 But if the place seals up and matter separates from it, and it remains like this for a long time; then know that it has already been completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And if matter does not separate from it, then know that it is deep-seated, or there is a corrupt opening within it, or something like this; whose reminder will come in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	 On the method of cauterizing the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	 Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	 When pain occurs in the kidneys due to cold or excessive flatulence, and it lessens because of this weakness of the patient, then you should cauterize him above the almenthenem on the kidneys themselves, with a cautery over each kidney with a small cautery, which comes before the remembrance.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	 And perhaps we will cauterize him a second time in that same place.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	 Why will three lines appear?
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	 Therefore, they will be more effective in the end.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	 § On the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	 Chapter 40
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	 When there is weakness and softening of the bladder from cold and moisture, to the point that the patient cannot hold urine, then you should cauterize him on the lower part of the abdomen over the bladder where the hairs of the pubis begin, with a cautery from the right side of the abdomen and another from the left. And let the length of this cauterization be according to the width of the thumb joint; and you should cauterize him with a lower back cautery or with two if you need them; and it should be as the small cautery comes before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	 § On the method of cauterizing the uterus.
Caput XLI.	 Chapter 41
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	 When there is cold and moisture in the uterus, which prevents impregnation and corrupts its menses, delaying their onset, and causing pain during their arrival, then it should be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel as we have said for the bladder, and with a cautery over the alcatim on the lower back, or with two if necessary; and let the cautery be small.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	 § On the method of cauterizing the ankle in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	 Chapter 42
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	 When mucous humors flow to the ankle and cause it to leave its place; and the sign of this is that one leg is longer than the other when compared, and the place of dislocation is found empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	 It is therefore necessary to cauterize the patient over a box of Anchae with a similar cautery circle. After marking it with wax around the box as it turns, so that the box itself falls into the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	 And let the cautery be of the form which has been described for the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	 If this cautery is not available to you, then use three cauteries: a large olive-oil cautery and make the depth of the cautery according to the thickness of the entire skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	 § On Cauterizing for Sciatica
Caput XLIII.	 Chapter XLIII
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	 When pain occurs in the bladder and its cause is cold and moisture, and the patient is treated with what we have said in the division of humors, but it does not help and the disease persists, then you must free the patient from thick humors with stinking pills or artificial pills and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	 Then cauterize him.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	 And the method of cautery is according to two methods: either a cautery with drying medicines or a cautery with fire. xspace
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	 A cautery with fire is done in many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	 One of these methods is to cauterize over the bladder itself with three triangular cauteries in this shape. ️
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	 And make them of good or bad depth.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	 And let the space between each cautery be the size of a thick finger, and let the cautery be made with olive oil.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	 Sometimes, however, the cautery is done in the middle over the head of the bladder itself. ️ ️ ️
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	 Why are there four cauteries?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	 And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form has been described for the cauterization of bladder dislocation, do so with one, so that the circle contains the entire bladder.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	 "And burn the thickness of the entire skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	 This is the method of cautery for sciatica when the pain clings to the hip itself and does not extend to the thigh and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	 But if it extends to the thigh and leg, then cauterize with two cauteries over the hip, on the spot where the patient indicates that the pain is, and your cautery four fingerbreadths towards the tendon briefly; and let the cautery be knife-like.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	 And let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	 But if the patient indicates that the pain extends almost to the toes of the foot, then cauterize there where he indicates with a point or three, or four, or more, as needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	 And if the patient indicates that the pain is under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize there with one knife-like cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	 And beware in all your cautery that you do not go with the cautery to the point of burning a large nerve or artery and thereby draw a harmful disease or contraction upon the patient.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	 And indeed I myself have seen one and another of those who cauterized over the tendon and carried the cautery to completion, and their leg swelled up until a tumor reached the foot and the whole thing burst, and the entire foot was corrupted; then came an opening in the belly, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	 But if the pain is in two parts at the same time, cauterize each one according to this manner.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	 And some wise men said in the cautery of the hip, whose method this is.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	 Make a similar awl from iron, whose diameter is half the width of a palm; and at its opening let there be according to the thickness of an almond, or slightly less; and inside that awl let there be a third awl.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	 And let there be a space between each samium equal to the thickness of the thumb; and let the samia be open on both sides; and let their height be like that of a knot, or two knots; and make for them a handle from iron, well fitted into the samia.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	 Then it should be heated in the fire until it turns red and sparks fly out; then it should be placed on a weak patient's side, above the healthy part of the chest.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	 Therefore, cauterize him with three round cauteries at once.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then leave him for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	 Afterwards, apply plasters with butter; and let the wound remain open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	 Albucasis said: "O my son, we have used this kind of cautery little because of the frightening appearance of it; and also, because few can bear its application.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	 However, for him who endures, it is among the good cauteries, and he who finds a place for it will be successful with it.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	 The cautery is also made with adherent medicines, such that you should make two samia having a perforated armilla, into which descends the pin of its door, either from bronze or iron, as long as the wall; whose height should be two knots, or similar to them.  />
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	 And let the space between the two be the thickness of a finger; and let them be open below and above; and let them contain each other in this manner.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	 Then place it on the chest of a weak patient lying on the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	 And press your hand firmly against the chest.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	 Then pour between the two samia warm water which has been heated a little by fire, and hold it for an hour; and let the patient endure its burning and its scorching, for he will find the burning like fire until the burning ceases.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 Then lift your hand with the instrument and wash away all the hot water from the wound with sweet water; then leave it alone for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	 And put butter on it until the blackness of the burn is removed; and leave it for some days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	 For it is most helpful in treatment.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	 But if the pain extends to the hip or thigh, make for him a bath in which there is water, as you did for the wound, in the same way.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	 And this is the method of hot water; and I have already written it down in the chapter on rectifying medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	 Take soda and unslaked lime in equal parts; grind both of them finely and put them in a new pot whose bottom is pierced with one small hole through which the liquid can pass, and under the bottom of the pot place another glass pot, and pour over the soda and lime sweet water so that it covers both by a finger's width; then press them firmly with your hand; and leave the pot until the sharp water descends into the lower part of the glass pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	 Then collect all that water and pour it over another lime; and strain it through a cloth until it is clear.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	 For then it will be very strong, which is used in many operations of medicine and in the cautery of other members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	 Because it performs the action of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	 And among the medicines that are used to cauterize wounds, there is also terebinth resin and almond oil and lime mixed with soap.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	 And indeed Galen reported the cure of a certain ancient man, by which he was cured of pain in his wound and sciatic vein; and he praised it greatly. 》
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	 And he said that no other treatment was needed, and that he was cured after one application until he reported that perhaps he had entered a bath house and came out of it already healthy.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	 And take it from a green sebet plant: and if you cannot find it fresh, take the dried kind, recently harvested. Grind it very finely with some fat, and place it on the ulcer where there is pain, either on the leg or in the hip. Bind it, and leave it on for three hours, or however long the patient feels relief from the burning sensation.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	 Then introduce him to a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	 When his body becomes sweaty, place him on a stool.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	 For the pain subsides and he is cured.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	 And know that no one should use cautery with these medicines unless after purging the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	 And Dioscorides said that goat dung, when used to cauterize the sciatic vein, helps it: and this is how you make the cautery.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	 Take wool and soak it in old oil, and place it on the deep place that is between the thumb of the foot and the ankle bone, which is closer to the ankle bone.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	 Then take dry goat dung and burn it in a fire until it becomes charcoal. ›
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	 Then place the charcoal on the wool and leave it until it goes out.
Deinde itera illud.	 Then repeat that process.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	 Do not cease to do this until the sensation reaches the ulcer and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	 And this method of cautery is called the goat dung cautery.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	 ¶ On the Cautery for Back Pain
Caput XLIIII.	 Chapter Forty-Four.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	 Sometimes back pain occurs due to many causes, such as injury, a blow, or excessive purging, and similar things, from the infusion of cold, wet matter. And indeed, cautery is only indicated in this particular case, which is caused by the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	 It is therefore necessary after the evacuation of the patient with foul-smelling pills and similar ones that three lines be made on the back where it hurts, according to the width of the almeidat itself, after marking with a cautery in each line five or more burns, as many as come from the strength of the patient's tolerance. And let the cauterization be done with a cautery point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	 And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries using the middle of a nail-shaped cautery according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	 On the method of cauterizing an incipient hump.
Caput XLV.	 Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	 This illness often happens to small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	 And the sign of its onset in children is that a stricture occurs in their breath as they rise and move, and it is found in the last vertebrae of the back and in its nodes, which have already begun to protrude above the other vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	 When you see it and wish to do this, then cauterize with a circular cautery according to this method.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	 And let the cautery take hold of each part of the vertebrae equally. If you wish to cauterize around the vertebra with a point cautery, make two or three lines and let the points be close together.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	 Then care for the place until it heals with what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	 And beware of applying a cautery to a hump caused by a nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	 On the method of cauterizing gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	 Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	 When the pains of the joints are from cold humors that flow into any part of the body, then when these pains occur in the feet, according to the custom of physicians, they properly name it gout.  ()
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	 When treating gout caused by cold with remedies and the pain is not removed, then a cautery will remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	 And it should be that he is cauterized after purging around the joint of the foot with many cauteries; and let the cautery be olive oil-based.
Cuius haec est forma.	 Whose form is this.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	 And if you need to prick on the surface of the foot, then do it with a small pricking iron.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	 If the pain ascends to the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize him on every knee with three or four cauteries from all sides, using the same clavile iron.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	 But if you need more of this cautery, then cauterize him again.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	 And do not plunge your hand with the cautery; rather let it be about as thick as the skin.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	 But if the pain ascends to the knees and back, then administer what we said about the cautery in its own chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	 But if the pain is only in the hands, then prick around the joints as two lines revolve.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	 But if any pain remains in the fingers, then prick them on every joint with a single prick, and also on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	 But if after days the pain ascends to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from all sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	 And do not purge the patient from a good diet and from taking medication.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	 For if a good regimen is followed and the phlegm is purged, he will be healed with God's help by means of this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	 Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	 When a rupture occurs in the groin and the intestine or scrotum descends to the testicle, and this is an urgent case, then it is necessary that you instruct the patient to abstain from food for that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	 And let him use laxatives so that his stool may pass from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	 Then let him sit between your hands on his back; and instruct him to hold his breath until it comes out, or a turd appears, or the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	 Then reduce him with your fingers, and mark the place of the rupture above the anus with a cautery, with a mark whose end is like half a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	 Then apply fire to the cautery until pus comes out and it throws off scabs.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	 Then reduce the intestine or turd back to its natural place.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	 Then have the assistant place his hand over the site to prevent the intestine from exiting; and you have now opened between the patient's thighs and placed a pillow underneath, and another servant on his legs, and another on his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	 Then place the cautery over that mark, with your hand holding the cautery upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	 And hold him until you reach his mouth with it; or repeat the process with another if you have not reached the mouth on the first try.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	 And be mindful of the exit of the intestine during your cautery, lest you burn it and cause death or great harm to the patient through it.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	 And know that when you do not reach the mouth with the cautery, your work is in vain.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	 And it is necessary for the cautery of infants to be fine, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with other ointments until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	 And let the patient lie on his back for forty days until the wound closes.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	 And it is necessary that you provide his food during the time of his treatment, so that it may soften his belly; so that the intestine does not come out at the attempt or discharge.  />
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	 Then, when he wants to get up after forty days, give him a well-made bandage and let him keep it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	 And let him be kept from labor, and from filling his stomach with food and drink, and from loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	 For when he follows this treatment, he is healed by a complete cure.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	 And I will describe the treatment of hernias with incisions in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	 But when hernias occur in the rest of the abdomen and are beginning and you wish that they not increase, then cauterize his hernia with a round cautery according to its size: and let what is burnt be one-third of it. )))
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	 Then treat him as we have said, and there will be no increase.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	 And some of the ancients have said that it should be cauterized with a triangular cautery in this shape.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	 After it is marked with the cautery, and a line is placed which is along its width on the upper side of the hernia, and another line below it.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	 And place your hand in the middle with a nail-shaped cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	 But the first cautery is easier and better. ))) )))
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing for pains from a fall or blow.
Caput XLVIII.	 Chapter 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	 When there is pain in certain members from a fall or blow, and the pain persists for a long time, and medicine does not help it, then it must be cauterized with a point-shaped cautery. ))) ))) )))
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	 And let the cautery be of every member according to its size and thinness and weakness and strength, and where the blow or pain is from that. ))) ))) ))) )))
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	 If he is healed from the first cautery, that is good. ))) ))) ))) ))) ))) )))
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	 "If not, then repeat on that same cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	 Because it is the custom of these pains to pass from one member to the next adjacent one.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Therefore you should follow them with a cautery until the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	 § On the manner of cauterizing in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	 Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	 Sometimes lepers are greatly helped by cautery.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	 And especially the kind of leprosy that comes from the corruption of phlegm and black bile. When you wish to cauterize it, be mindful of this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	 If the leprosy is in its beginning stage and you have treated it with what we mentioned in the division, and it does not descend or stop; and you fear for the patient that corruption may overcome his entire complexion; then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head, a second below it towards the forehead at the hairline, two above each temple, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	 And finally, place your hand with the cautery briefly on it, so that it makes a small impression on the skin and causes the scabs to detach from it; this will relieve the exhalation of thick vapors from it. Also cauterize the spleen itself as we have previously described.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	 But if the leprosy has already spread over the patient and is clearly visible; then you must cauterize with these cauteries that we have mentioned on the head, and one cautery on the tip of the nose, and two cauteries on each cheek, and two on each side of the neck, and six on each side of the back, and a large one on the scrotum at the root of the penis and one above it in the bellybutton; and two on each shoulder blade, that is, with one on each shoulder blade and two on each knee: one on each knee and two on each elbow, and two on each wrist, and two on each side of his chest. And cauterize him on every joint among the joints of the fingers of both his hands and feet; and cauterize on each heel of his feet and on each palm of his hands.  />
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	 And beware of the nerves that are on the back of the heel, lest you burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	 And sometimes it is cauterized with a hot iron over the pubic bone, and another over the xiphoid process of the sternum, and another over the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	 And know that the more you apply the hot iron, it is more beneficial and effective.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	 And know that the sick person does not feel pain from the hot iron as much as a healthy person would, because their body is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	 And the hot irons should be made according to size and shape for different limbs and joints, as has been mentioned in the types of surgical instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then treat the wounds with a poultice made from ground herbs and honey, and continue other treatments until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	 On the Method of Cauterizing When Someone is Insensible.
Caput L.	 Book One
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	 When a limb becomes insensible and is treated with medicines, oils, and plasters, but does not heal, then cauterize the insensible limb with hot irons, according to the size or shape of the limb.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	 And let your hot iron penetrate slightly into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	 And sometimes it is cauterized for the numbness that occurs in the hand or foot, at the spine of the back near where the nerves that move that limb emerge; and the numbness will be removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	 But do not attempt this unless you are knowledgeable in the dissection of limbs and the exit points of the nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	 On the Method of Cauterizing for Whitlows.
Caput LI.	 Book Fifty-One
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	 When a whitlow becomes old and nothing helps it from the healing arts, then cauterize it slightly with a deep hot iron according to the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with herb flour and lentils with rose oil, and arnoglossa leaves, and dove's blood, and swallow's blood: let there be an equal part of each. Let all these be mixed together and smeared on a cloth, and adhere to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	 On the method of cauterizing in cancer.
Caput LII.	 Chapter 52
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	 When the cancer is beginning and you wish to stop it, then cauterize it with a circular cautery around its circumference, as if turning [a wheel].
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	 However, the wise have said that it should be cauterized with the final cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	 But this does not seem right to me, because I fear that it will cause an ulceration; and indeed I have seen this happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	 And it is more appropriate to cauterize around its circumference with a circle, as we have said, or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	 On the method of cauterizing in abscesses.
Caput LIII.	 Chapter 53
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	 When someone has an abscess and it is delayed in ripening, either because of the excess humour causing it, or because of the weakness of the patient when they are elderly and have little blood, or because of the time and the desire to hasten the ripening of the abscess, then cauterize around its circumference with many small puncturing cauteries.
Deinde dimitte eam.	 Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	 For it will hasten in ripening on its own.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	 But if you wish to pierce it with a cautery, then heat the cautery, which has this form: ¶ [A drawing of the cautery may be included here.]
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	 And place it in the middle of the abscess, until it penetrates the skin. Let the cautery be from the weakest patient, so that the course of pus may be facilitated.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	 About the method of cauterizing in malignant ulcers.
Caput LIIII.	 Chapter 46.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	 The ulcer is nothing but corruption moving through the limb, and it eats away at that limb, just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	 Therefore, if you see an ulcer in a place that can bear cautery with fire, then burn it much with fire, both small and large cauteries, according to what is suitable for the place where the ulcer is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	 Then cauterize it on all sides until you have completely removed all the corruption and nothing of it remains at all.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	 Then leave it for three days, and place ground sulfur mixed with oil on the cauterized places, until all the scabs are removed and all corruption is eliminated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	 Then treat it with flesh-generating ointments.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	 Therefore, if you see that after three days healthy flesh is born, in which there is no corruption, it is good. ️
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery on whatever remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	 And the ulcer should be treated at times with sharp medicine. ️
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	 For it arises in the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	 However, cautery with fire is of swifter help; and I have already spoken of its cauterization with sharp medicine in the division; therefore take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	 ¶ About the method of cauterizing in nails and warts.
Caput LV.	 Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	 Many times this illness occurs in the lower parts of the feet; and it is a thick, rough substance that injures the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	 And there are two types of cautery in them: cautery with fire, and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	 As for the one with fire, use a concave cautery like a vulture's feather, made of iron according to the size that can contain the nail from all sides; and let it have thin edges. ️ ️ ️
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	 Then place the heated instrument on the nail.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	 Then rotate the hand with the cautery around the nail until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail, and leave it for three days until it begins to emit pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	 Then apply a plaster with crushed wild mallows mixed with salt, and leave the plaster on it overnight.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	 It will be uprooted from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for the place with a flesh-generating ointment until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	 But if they do not convert and often occur on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet, then administer the cautery with hot water. And it is that you take a tube made of bronze, or iron, or from a vulture's feather, and place it on the nail, or althelul.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	 Then pour a small amount of hot water into the tube; hold your hand and rotate it with some pressure for a short while, so that the edge of the tube is impressed on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way to the depth, to the root of the nail; and let the patient wait for an hour over the biting of the hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	 Then leave it, for the nail will be uprooted with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	 Do this one after another until you have treated all those that are on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	 Then care for them after they have been uprooted with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	 ¶ On the method of cauterizing in tremors.
Caput LVI.	 Chapter 61.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	 When trembling occurs to someone from cold in the nerves, or from tertian fever, or something else, then it is necessary that you cauterize him with four or five cauteries on the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra a cautery, and on his chest a cautery, and on his stomach a cautery.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	 The tremor quiets with oil cautery, and health quickly returns from cold illness.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	 On the manner of cauterizing according to Albathar.
Caput LVII.	 Chapter 57.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	 Sometimes Albathar expels foul things from the body, that is, pustules which are formed from coarse corrupt matter.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	 Therefore, as soon as they appear, they should be cauterized with a fine cautery made of myrtle wood, the end of which is set on fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	 Or with the root of long aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	 Or with a lentil-shaped cautery. ︎
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	 And sometimes they are cauterized with the adenoma at the beginning of its expulsion in this manner, and they do not increase; and the excess causing them is broken up, and they heal from it.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	 However, that should be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	 On the manner of cauterizing a wound to stop bleeding from an artery.
Caput LVIII.	 Chapter 58. ︎
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	 It often happens that there is bleeding from an artery cut in a wound, which occurs externally or during the incision of an aposteme, or of a member's cautery, and similar to these; and it is difficult to cut it off.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 Therefore, when this happens to someone, quickly bring your hand to the opening of the artery and place your index finger on it. And press it hard until the blood is blocked under your finger and nothing comes out of it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then put a small oil cautery and several large ones into the fire, and blow on them until they are very hot. ︎ ︎
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one of them, either small or large, according to the wound and the place where the artery is cut, and put the cautery on the vein itself after you quickly remove your finger; and hold the cautery until the bleeding stops.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If the clot is expelled by raising the finger from the orifice of the artery and extinguishing the cautery, then take another cautery quickly from those that are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Therefore, do not stop doing it with one after another until the blood is stopped.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And beware lest you burn the nerve that is there and another evil befall the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from the artery, it is not possible to stop it unless by one of four means, especially if the artery is large.
