Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Either with a cautery, as we said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it is extracted, its ends contract and the blood stops.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or let it be tied with a strong thread.  /> Et scias quod hoc potest fieri in omni loco corporis, praeter caput et manibus, quoniam ibi non est uiuentem, sed mortuam carnem.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or apply to it medicines that have the property of stopping blood, and bind it with a decent bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 But he who applies its stopping with a ligature and tightening with cloth or the application of burning substances and similar things does not help it at all, except rarely.  /> Sed quando arteria est parua, tunc possunt abscindere sanguinem per unam de his quatuor rebus, nisi quando est in capite vel in collo.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 But if this happens to someone and there is no physician present or medicine, then let him begin with the position of the finger on the orifice of the vein itself, as we have said, and very tight binding until the blood is stopped from above the wound and onto the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 And do not remove the finger, and pour cold water of very intense cold over it until the blood freezes and thickens and stops.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 And meanwhile, he should consider what is needed from a cautery or from medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 The End of the First Part
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 The Book of Surgery by Al-Zahrawi (Albucasis), Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 On Incision, Perforation, and Bloodletting in Wounds and Similar Conditions.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 We have already said in the first chapter about every illness in which it is suitable to use hot iron or burning medicine, its occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cautery.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And there I placed chapters from the head to the feet.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 And I will proceed in this chapter along the same path, so that it may ease the search for its questioner.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before I begin that, it is necessary for you to know, O sons, that in this chapter there is a similarity to what is in the first chapter about cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And because of this, greater care is necessary, because in the operation that is in this chapter, evacuation often occurs with blood, which stands at the opening of a vein, or incision above an abscess, or opening of an exit wound, or treatment of a wound, or extraction of an arrow, or incision above a stone, and similar things: all of these are associated with trembling, fear, and death occurs in many of them.  />
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 And I warn you not to allow doubt to fall upon you, for sometimes people with various illnesses come to you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 Among them is one who becomes angry with his illness, and for him death is light because of the intensity of what he finds from his illness and the length of its evil.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 And with his illness is fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 And among them is one who gives you his flute and enriches you with it, hoping for health, but his illness is deadly.  />  />  />
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 It is not appropriate for you to agree with the one who comes to you with such a method.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 Let your caution be greater than your greed and your impatience.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 And do not presume over anything from it, unless after a certain knowledge which verifies to you the praiseworthy outcome to which it has come.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 And use in the treatment of all your patients prediction and indication concerning that to which it is suitable for health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 For in this you have assistance towards gaining fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 May God inspire you, sons, with His understanding, and may He not take away your guidance and inspiration from you, for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 And I myself have arranged this Chapter by dividing it into sections, following what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from the neck to the feet: so that your search for what you want from it and need may be made easier.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 ¶ On the treatment of water that collects in the heads of children.
Caput I.	 Chapter I
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 Know that this illness often happens to children at birth or when the midwife tightly grasps the child's head without gentleness. ‌
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 And sometimes it happens also for an unknown cause that is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 And I myself have not seen this illness in anyone other than children, and every one of them that I saw died quickly because of it; therefore, it seemed to me to pass over treating it. ‌
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 And I myself saw one of them, a child whose head was filled with water, and his head swelled every day until he could no longer sit up because of the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this moisture either collects between the skin and bone or accumulates beneath the bone on the skull (cranium).
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 And the operation in it, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then you should make one slit in the middle of the head; and let the length of the slit be like two knuckles, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of the instrument.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 If, therefore, the moisture has increased more and the abscess is larger, then make those two slits according to this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if the moisture is under the bone, and its sign is that you see the sutures of the head open on all sides; and water sinks when you press it with your hand towards the inside, and it does not hide itself from you: then you should make three slits in the middle of the head according to this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then bind the slits with cloths and wool.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then dress it on top with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then loosen the bandage, and care for the wound with soft linens and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 And do not stop binding the head evenly.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 And feed the patient with all dry food of little moisture, until the part is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 And another method of incision is that you should observe where the size of the abscess and the collection of water appear.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 For sometimes it is more on the back of the head, or on the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left side.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore, with your incision go to where you see the abscess and the collection of water; and cut it according as is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And take care not to cut an artery, lest blood flow out and the patient die from that flow along with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 ¶ About the Incision of the Arteries that are behind the ears. ›
Caput II.	 Chapter 2
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When someone has catarrh in the eyes or chest and it becomes chronic, and medical treatment is of no benefit, then the final treatment for that person is to cut these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore, when you wish to cut them, it is necessary for the patient to shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then rub the area with a rough cloth so that the arteries become apparent.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let the patient tie his own neck with any of his own cloths. ‌
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then observe where the pulse of the vein is felt.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And the locations of both are in the depressed areas behind the ears, and rarely are they hidden except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark both locations with hot iron and cut each with a sharp razor, making the incision reach the bone: and do this across the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if you wish, insert the razor under the artery and cut it from above with the same incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 And let the length of the incision be about two fingers' width joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 For when the vein is cut, blood comes out with a pulsating flow, which jumps frequently to the inner parts. ‌
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 But if the artery is not perceived by touch, then measure from the ear the distance of three fingers' width.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark with hot iron and find it down to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And that which should be emitted from the blood is six ounces, and perhaps you will emit more or less than that.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 All of this according to the amount which appears to you from the strength of the patient and the fullness of his artery. ‌ ‌
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then observe at the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 Then if there is anything left at the bone from the scab, cut it away so that a hot abscess does not occur. Then bind the wound with cloths of linen fabric.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with ointment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 About the extraction of the temporal arteries.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When someone has an old migraine or severe cold due to the acrid humors and heat in the temples, or when it is a severe old headache of a similar nature, and medical treatments are applied according to their methods but do not help: then we have found, through experience with these illnesses, that extracting the temporal arteries or cauterizing them, as we have described, is effective.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 And the method for extracting them is as follows: let the patient shave off the hair on their temples and expose the visible temporal artery.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 For it is made apparent to you by its own pulse, and rarely does it remain hidden except in a few people or during severe cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 But if it is hidden from you, then have the patient tie their head with any cloth they have; afterwards, rub the area with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or apply steam to the area with hot water until it appears clearly before you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take the spatula that I mentioned earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then use it to easily peel away the skin until you reach the artery. 🙂
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then insert the hook into it and pull it upwards until you have extracted it from the skin and made it exit completely from all the underlying layers. 😊
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 But if the artery is thin, then wrap it around the tip of the hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut off a section according to how much the ends can be extended and contracted without causing any bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 For if it is not cut or severed, the blood will not rise at all. 😊
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then evacuate from the blood vessel six ounces of blood until three remain. 😊
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large: then you must tie it in two places with double-threaded, strong silk or gut string, so that putrefaction does not rush to the wound before its healing, and blood loss may occur.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut the excess between the two ties.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do this at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery until the edges are cut off, using a surgical knife; so that it may stand in the place of that operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 And this is a better operation, unless the patient has a fever or a hot constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because a cautery is among those things which help to end moistures.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore, it is a better remedy.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the removal of the arteries, the place should be filled with old cloths, and fine bandages should be placed on top in a pleasing manner.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after the dissolution, it should be cleaned with dry medicines that cause flesh to grow, and with ointments, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If during the operation blood flows from the artery, then quickly cut it with a cautery or fill the place with tow; and keep your hand pressed until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 But if you do not have either of these at hand, then place your finger over the spot until the blood clots.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 And soak the place with very cold water, until the sharpness subsides and it is bound as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And because it is easier and simpler to extract the vein by cauterizing it with this double-bladed cautery; let the sharpness of the two blades be like an almagdal.  />And after placing the blade, burn until it reaches the second tie.  />And this operation should not be done without a ligature, lest putrefaction enter into the wound before its healing.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 Truly, they are much sharper than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 For if they were sharp like two knives, the cold would hasten to both; and they would not cut flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Therefore, since there is some thickness in them, the heat of the fire is retained within them, and flesh is cut quickly; thus this work is better than any other, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	 And let the space between the two knives be the thickness of a finger after you mark two places with cautery; and place both of them very hot until they reach the mouth, and cut the vein in two places so that what is between its ends is lengthened.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 For they do not fully coalesce with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 ¶ On the care for acute and persistent tear flow from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When tears are persistent and their flow comes from the veins that are outside on top of the head, and medical treatment with medicines does not help them, and you see the face of the sick person already redden, and he feels in his forehead a sensation like the movement of ants: and his eyes are emaciated, moist, so much so that their hair is corroded by the corrosion: and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of the tears; then the ancients needed this operation for their treatment, and they named it a cure with the sword. 》
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And you should advise the sick person to shave the hair from his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then make three equally spaced cuts in the forehead along its length; and let the length of each cut be like two fingers, and one cut should be halfway along the nose on the middle of the forehead, and the second one should be a little way from the movement of the temples, and the third one on the other side: and beware of cutting the arteries that are on both sides; and keep your hand away from the continuation of the two jaws, and let the space of all the cuts be the size of three connected fingers; and have ready a piece of sponge, or many dry cloths, with which you may absorb the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert a thin reed with two sharp ends, the shape of which is shown next.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the incision near the temple to the second incision; and scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the flesh that is over the mouth.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then do likewise from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then remove that reed and insert another instrument into the first incision, which is called a sharp scalpel, smooth on one side and not sharp on the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And place the sharp edge towards the attached flesh with the skin, and the smooth edge towards the mouth; and push it until it reaches the middle fissure; and cut along with it all the blood vessels that descend from the head to the eyes, except that the incision continues to what is visible on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then do this in the middle fissure to the other fissure. ●
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And after an equal amount of blood has run out, press upon the places where the blood is clotted.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then place a liniment of old lard into every fissure, and upon them put little poultices soaked in wine, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And see to it that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 And on the third day, release the bandage, and administer a large quantity of infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with balm ointment and the other things by which wounds are treated until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 ¶ On the treatment of acute tears and colds that come to the eyes from inside the head.
Caput V.	 Chapter V
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone has acute and painful catarrhs that are persistent: and you see their eyes weakened, small, and their sight already impaired; and the eyelids ulcerated, and the hairs fall out from them, and there is an acute pain in the depth of the head, causing distress, and sneezing follows: then know from these signs that those humors and catarrhs do not come except from many veins. ● ● ●
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 And a better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 And it is, as you would advise the patient to shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make an incision in that fissure one in the middle of the forehead or slightly to one side according to its width, and begin with the incision from the left temple to the right: and let the cut go as far as the mouth; and keep your hand away from the temples which move during chewing until the mouth is revealed; and dry all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate between the two lips of the incision with an old cloth or with linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then bind it above with little woolen bands; and moisten the woolen bands with wine and oil so that a hot abscess does not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you loose that [bandage], and you see that the hot abscess is already diminishing, then it is necessary for you to scrub the mouth until flesh begins to grow there.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then care for the patient with a drying diet that causes flesh to grow, as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony and prepare from them an ointment, and apply it to the growth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 ¶ On the care of what falls into the ear.
Caput VI.	 Chapter Six.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron and glass; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is a liquid substance, such as water and vinegar and things similar to them; or some sort of animal.  />
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 Therefore, when a stone or something of the kind that does not grow nor is added [to the ear] falls into it, expose the ear to the sun; and if you see the stone, then pour into the ear some oil of violets or sesame oil.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer an extraction and make him sneeze with condiments, and close the nostrils at the onset of sneezing, after you have placed pieces of cloth or wool around the ear and stretched the ear upward.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 Often indeed it goes out with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 But if it does not go out, then administer the extraction of it with Gesty, that is, fine pizigares; the shape of which is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 If therefore it goes out with gesty, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not, then administer the extraction of it with a fine blunt hook of few folds.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 If it does not go out through that, then make a tube of bronze and insert the end of the tube deeply into the ear hole, and close what is around the tube with softened wax mixed with oil, so that there is no way for air except through the tube: then extract with a strong exhalation.  />
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 Often indeed it goes out with what we have described.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 But if it does not go out this way, then take from hekalimbat or from visco, that is, prepared glue with which birds are caught, a small amount; and place it on the end of a stick after you have wound over it a cotton cloth neatly placed: then insert it into the ear hole easily, after you have dried the ear from moisture.  />  />
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 If it does not go out with all that we have described, then hasten to cut open, before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 And the method of cutting is to bleed the sick person first in the cephalic vein, and extract from him blood according to his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the sick person sit between your hands, and turn his ear upward, and find a small opening at the root of the ear in its fatty part in a depressed place itself; and let the opening be lunar-shaped, until you reach the stone: then remove it with what is possible for you from instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then wash the opening from your hour with speed and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 But if what falls into the ear is one of those seeds that grow and swell: then you should extract it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 But if it does not come out on its own, then take a thin, fine probe in this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And apply with it the removal of that kind of seed which falls into the ear and does not come out when you think the seed is already moistened by the heat of the ear, until you break it up into many pieces: then remove those pieces with a hook or with a fine probe or with suction, as we said, for its removal is made easier.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 In the case of water which enters the ear, it is necessary for the sick person to sneeze first, and already his ear has been filled with some old cooked food: and he lies down on that ear in which there is water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 If it therefore comes out through it, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if not: then take many stones the length of a finger, thin and smooth, and heat them briefly with fire, and let the sick person insert one into the opening of his ear: and he should jump on one foot, and strike the stone which is in the ear with another stone.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Do not therefore cease to do this with stones until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 And now the water comes out so that you take one of reed or rush and insert its end into the ear: and light the other end with fire until it is almost consumed.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then take another reed and do this many times until all the water comes out: and remove it with a syringe as previously described for the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 But in the case of an animal entering it, if it is small-bodied like a flea, care for it as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 "But if it is of the body's main part and is noticeable to the senses, then administer its removal with tweezers and hooks, and its resolution is easier than all those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 "However, when treating a worm born in the ear, if you care for it with what we mentioned in division and in dealing with fumigation, your treatment is of no use; then you must look at the ear in sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 "Therefore, if something appears there from the worms, then remove it with tweezers or with fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 "But if nothing appears there, then take a cannula whose form is such that it is narrow at the bottom and wide at the top; insert its fine tip into the ear according to the amount the patient can tolerate; then suck with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 "Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 "But if they do not obey you in coming out, then coat the circumference of the cannula with wax, as I said about the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 "But if they do not come out with what we have said, then administer the fumigations which the ancients have already experienced in killing worms; and you will find it in the section on fumigations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 "And let your pouring be with which you pour oil and medicine into the ear using this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 "As you see, make it of silver or bronze, narrow below where there is a small hole, and wide above.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 "So let the plunger that is within the hollow of the cannula be made neatly of iron.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 "And if you wish, take a reed and wrap its tip with cotton in a neat layer; then pour oil or juice, or whatever you want from these medicines into the cannula; and let it be in the ear; then insert the reed with the cotton on top, and press it gently with your hand until the oil is forced into the hollow of the ear, and the patient feels it inside; and let what is poured into the ear already be slightly heated by fire; and take care that what is distilled into it is not very cold; for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 The care of the accidental fall of gold.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 Sometimes certain infants emerge from their mothers' wombs unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 And it has happened to some people that the fall of gold occurs in the ear canal from a wound or flesh born within it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this fall of gold sometimes occurs deep within the ear canal, which vision cannot follow; and sometimes it happens near the outer edge of the ear canal, and vision follows it.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, that which occurs deep within the ear and which sight does not grasp is difficult to cure in most cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in that which vision follows, you must place the ear of the patient in the sun and look into it; then if you see an apparent fall of gold, open it with a fine spatula, whose form is as follows: let its tip be small in width, of which one part should be sharp, and let the rest of the spatula be of two smooth sides so that it does not injure the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 If, however, the fall of gold is from flesh born within the ear canal, then hold it with a fine hook and cut it with great ease until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 But if the fall of gold is deep within the ear, then take a fine, smooth wire and heat it slightly with fire; then insert it into the ear canal. ething.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If you feel the fall of gold with it, which the patient finds with difficulty of hearing, strive to open it with ease; and beware lest you wound the nerve of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place in the ear a piece of linen according to the width of the ear canal, which you have rolled in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are confident about the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take linen and pour rose water over it, and sprinkle finely ground sarsaparilla over it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you see the ear already infected with boils: then you must extract the pus, and allow it to be covered with another poultice, which you will wrap in a cloth that has been made with rose oil, until the hot abscess is settled; then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 If there is bleeding: then soak a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it on the ear; and use the rest of the treatment which cuts off the aforementioned bleeding in the treatise on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 About the care for sty in the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter Eight
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 These styes that occur in the eyelids of the eye are sometimes wet and sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore, you should hold them with tweezers or with a hook, and cut them off at their roots with a scalpel.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then place powdered sulfur on the places.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 If there is bleeding from them, then cauterize them with a fine lens-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And it is better to cauterize after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 For often they return when some of their roots remain.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return. )))
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 About the care for chalazions in the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	 Chapter Nine
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 Often there occurs in the eyelids something which resembles a chalazion in its strength and hardness, and on account of this it is called "grain"; and it is an accumulation of thick fluid in the upper eyelid and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 The treatment for them is to observe whether the grain has developed inside it, as can be seen from the eyelid, and they move in every direction, and its nature is easy. ))) )))
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Then find a slit of equal width on it.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then peel it from every part with ease until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then hang it with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 But if its cutting is not prepared for you until after you penetrate the eyelid with a slight cut, then that harms the patient somewhat.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 But if the opening is large: then join it with stitches and care for it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 For an ointment restores it and makes it fleshy again.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 And if the grain is inclined towards the inner surface of the ear, then turn back the eyelid and hang the grain with a hook, except that you need to make a cut and press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 But if the eyelid is lengthened by the cut, this causes no harm at all. 》
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then wash the eye after removing the grain with salt water and care for the place with what makes it fleshy until the patient heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 ¶ About treating trachoma of the eyelids.
Caput X.	 Chapter 10
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 Chapter X. Trachoma is a fat that forms in the membranes of the upper eyelid, and this happens especially to children. It weighs down their eyes, they get colds in the mornings, and they cannot look at the sun because tears rush into them. For this reason you see them constantly lying on their faces, and sleeping on them. Their eyelids are wet under their eyebrows, which inflammation has already covered; and a visible Axirnath appears to the eye. And when you press the place with your fingers, you feel the Axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the method of treatment is for the patient to put his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 Then take a cloth of flax, and prepare bandages in it, and make from them a circular bandage according to the size that contains Axirnath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place it on top of it and press it with your fingers on every side, so that Axirnath is collected in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 Then find in the middle of that wetness a small opening with an incision knife across its width, and let the cut not be deeper than that made in bloodletting.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 Or you should look for the whole skin until you reach Axirnath, for in many cases Axirnath proceeds from the cut according to the shape of a white piece of fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Therefore extract it with the cloth that you have put between your fingers on the outside; and you roll your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed; and be careful not to add anything into the cut so that you do not reach with the knife to the eye, and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 But if Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the cut, then you should add a little into the cut with ease until Axirnath proceeds out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then extract it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Then soak the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them on the spot, and bind it with small bandages.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And there are some people who grind salt and place it on the cut so that whatever remains of that wetness is dissolved.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 But if a hot abscess occurs in that place, then treat it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 ¶ About the kinds of Ataxmir of the eye, that is, when the eyelid of the eye becomes soft, so that it blinks as it should not.
Caput XI.	 Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs grow in the eyelids beyond their natural course and are ignored, they harm the eye and cause various illnesses such as constant tears, softening of the eyelids, and cataracts, eventually leading to the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 The treatment of ataxia of the eye is carried out in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 Either by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 Or with a sharp instrument, as previously mentioned in the chapter on cautery.  />
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 Or ataxia of the eye is treated by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 Or by means of reeds, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 You should place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then, with your left hand, turn back the eyelid of the eye.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If it is turned back, that is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 If not, insert a needle with thread from the lower part of the eyelid and make the needle penetrate with the thread above it, near the hair itself, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs grow; then pull the thread upwards with the eyelid and turn it back with a rod.  />  />
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find, within the eyelid under the added hairs, with a small spoon from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then pull out the thread and place a small piece of cotton or cloth under the eyelid; then mark the eyelid with wax in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, it is necessary that the shape be made according to the size and thickness of the eyelid; for it varies greatly among people.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 There are some who need a large piece to be cut out of the eyelid, corresponding to the amount that is softened by the eyelid.  />  />  •
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then, when you find the eyelid space over the two lines that you have marked, begin from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct, and let there be one cut near the natural hairs, as thick as a finger.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then insert the hook into one of the two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then remove it completely.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then join the two lips with stitches using a fine woolen thread and a needle: clean away the blood, and make the excess threads stick together above the two eyebrows with some adhesive substances, if you wish to do so; but if not, it does not matter.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then leave the stitches and threads for three or four days; afterwards, treat it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, leave the wound without stitches and treat it with something that dries and closes it.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid will be raised at the sealing of the wound and its joining, but it will be better afterwards.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 Ancient people taught this method of treatment to Ataxmir.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 However, there is concern for the patient in this, and it comes from good treatment; there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And another method is also found in Ataxmir, and it is to mark a shape on the eyelid like the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have said.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then raise the eyelid with three separate or joined hooks according to this following shape; then cut away the excess with small scissors according to this shape, with an equal depth of cut.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 But if you cannot hold the hook and it does not match up, then take a needle with thread in it and insert it in the middle of the shape; and insert another thread near the greater tear duct and a second thread near the lesser tear duct; and gather the threads between your fingers with equal tension. 
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then raise your hand with an equal lift: and raise the skin above which the knot is marked, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind together the two lips of the wound with a stitch: and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 But if an abscess occurs at your incision or cut: stitch that abscess with a suture and similar things from the soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes it happens to the eyelids as well, so that its hairs turn inward.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore you must use what we have said about the incision; but the stitch is more artful for both [eyelids].
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 ¶ On the care of trachoma with conjunctivitis.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 And it is [done] by turning back the eyelid and cutting the fissure that is inside, as I have said.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 Then skillfully make two cannulae or two fine sticks whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and their width should be less than the width of a spindle. And you have already cut at the extremities of both from both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 Then bind each one with care over that which protrudes from the eyelid of the eye, and tie together both sticks from both sides with a strong knot, and leave it for several days. 》
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 For the skin held tightly will die, and turn black, and putrefy, until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 If it is delayed, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 Therefore, when it is consolidated, raise the eyelid: and the hairs do not prick.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 And this is the form of the two cannulae which you should make according to this figure and measure in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 ¶ On raising hairs that prick in the eye with a needle. 》
Caput XII.	 Chapter Twelve.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 The operation for this is as follows: take a fine needle and insert into it a fine, soft silk thread.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 Then you will tie the ends together with two very fine knots; and the length of the threads should be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 Then prepare another fine thread under the Alinxotati in a short section, and if you wish, tie the ends together.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 Then let the patient place his head on your lap, and let it be near the sun so that the operation can be clearly seen; for this is a delicate or subtle operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 Then insert the needle with the Alinxotati into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate quickly into the eyelid until you extract a natural hair from above. ↑
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then pull the hair up to just above the Alinxotati and insert that hair into the Alinxotati; if there is one, or two, or three, no more than that.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then pull your hand with it until the hair comes out with the Alinxotati and the eyelid along with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 But if the Alinxotati is pulled out and the hair does not come out with it, pull the Alinxotati downwards with the thread that you prepared in it until the Alinxotati comes out of the upper hole, and you see it with your eyes; then you will pull the Alinxotati and the thread, and extract both, and close the eye; and leave it closed for two days or three, until the hair adheres to its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 If the hair is short, then either associate a long hair with it from the natural hairs and lift it up together; or leave it until it lengthens over time, and then lift it up.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 ¶ On the care of the Alxatrati that occurs on the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this happens to the eye, it is called leprosy.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And this leprosy is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 The accidental kind occurs from the healing of a wound, cut, or cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 And the manner of operating on it is that you should cut through that healing, separate its edges, and place a linen thread between them, and tie it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 And it is not fitting to use things that dry and constrict in its treatment, for if you do this, the leprosy returns worse than before; rather, use things that soften, such as fenugreek, embrocation with water in which althea and flax seed have been cooked, and diachylon ointment, which has been liquefied with some oil. And wrap a linen thread with it and treat with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 And your treasure of treatment is to strive by all means that it does not heal according to the first form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 And this operation which we have spoken of is nothing but a correction of the leprosy, so that the form of the place does not entirely return as it was before.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 ¶ On the treatment of leprosy which occurs on the lower eyelid and is a wrinkle or contraction upward toward the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This leprosy which occurs below is what is truly called leprosy.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 It is both natural and accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 And the accidental kind occurs from a wound, or cut, or cautery, and similar things. 
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 And the way of operating on it is that you should take a needle with a double thread, and dip it in ink, and make it penetrate from the left lacrimal to the right lacrimal, until the thread reaches the two ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then stretch the flesh upwards with a needle, and cut it with a broad scalpel.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 If therefore the figure of the eyelid returns as is fitting, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, take a thread and place it in the slit, and turn the eyelid with it. And find two slits on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two slits be from the two corners of the incision, until they meet and form a corner; until when they come together the figure will be like this figure, which is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then remove that flesh in the amount that its sharp side is below that which follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then gather the separated parts: or sew them together with a thread of wool.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then treat them with what we have said about softening ointments and linens until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 And if ectropion occurs from the slit or suture, or from cautery, then it is necessary to cut a flat slit under the eyelashes, even as has been said before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate between the two lips with a linen thread, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 And the summary of the treatment for ectropion, whether it is above or below, is that this operation should be performed according to the preparation from the type of ectropion.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 For indeed it [ectropion] is of many diverse forms; and a skilled craftsman prepares his ingenuity in whatever way is possible for him, so that he may bring the figure back to its natural form, or close to it, and the patient himself, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in many arrangements.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 ¶ On the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 Sometimes this consolidation occurs in many people, so that the upper eyelid consolidates with the white of the eye and prevents its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore, you should insert the tip of a needle under the eyelid and lift it up, or extend it with a hook; then cut the adhesion with a fine spatula that is not sharp like the incision spatulas but rather slightly blunt so as not to disturb the patient during the operation, and remove the spatula, lest it injure the eye with its sharpness. And let your incision be as if you were excoriating that adhesion easily, until when the eyelid returns to its natural shape, and the entire adhesion heals.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then pour salt water into the eye and wash it with water, or distill onto it from a sieve made of crushed gum dissolved in water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate the eyelid from the eye with a linen cloth; and place on the eye wool soaked in egg white; and after the third day, use a sieve and bandages until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 ¶ On the incision of the nail and the prominence of the tear gland.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail is in two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Either it is nervous and similar to a dry sponge, thin.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 Or it is not nervous and similar to frozen white moisture; when this is touched with iron or you try to catch it with a hook, it breaks off and the hook does not stick into it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And both types do not begin except from the larger tear gland, until it gradually extends to cover the vision and prevent light and eye movement.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the way of operating in its incision is: so that the patient places his head in your lap. 》 》
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open his eyes, and raise his eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Then gather the nail with a small hook, and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	 Then take a needle and insert into it a hair from the hairs of a horse, ox, or cow; and let the thread be strong, and slightly double the end of the needle, and place it in the middle of the nail: and penetrate it with the needle, and tie the nail with the thread, and extend it upwards: and remove the skin with the hair on the side of the nail that follows the pupil, as if you sew it with the hair to its very end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	 Then cut the remaining part at the root of the lacrimal gland with a fine scalpel or small scissors: and leave the natural lacrimal flesh as is, so that persistent tearing does not occur from the incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	 And sometimes the nail is extended with a hook alone; or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	 Then it should be scraped with a soft scalpel of this shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	 And take care that the scalpel does not touch the corneal membrane, lest it cause a tear and pierce the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then after the incision, put some crushed salt or a sieved powder of ziniar into the eye, and leave it until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	 Then care for him with what is necessary until he is healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	 If the nail is not fleshy and you cannot insert a needle into it or fix a hook in it, then this type of nail is often treated with medications and heals as I have described in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	 If you wish to cut it, then open the eye of the patient and take a thin, soft, and weakly sharpened scalpel of this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	 And scrape the surface of the nail with great fineness.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	 If you see that it becomes rarefied and fragmented, and a furrow is impressed upon it, then distill into the eye from an hourglass made of tin or red glass, or crushed salt: and fill the eye until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 Then repeat the same procedure until all of it is removed.
