Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	 Unless there is a hot abscess in your eye; then leave that [procedure] alone and treat the abscess until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the procedure with the furrow until it heals.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	 If the prominence of the tear-producing flesh causes great harm in the eye, hang it with a hook and cut off a portion of it; but do not finish the incision, so that the flow of tears may not be interrupted.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	 Then distill into a red glass or tin hourglass until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	 § On the Incision for Alguardenic and the Flesh Born in the Eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	 Sometimes a red fleshy substance is born in the eyes of some people, either composed or placed over [the eye], until it covers the pupil or approaches it, or presses on the eyelids and perhaps turns the eyelids outward; and it resembles a rosebud.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And the procedure for this is also that the patient should place his head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	 Then open his eyes and gather all that flesh with suitable hooks; and hold it with one forceps or tweezers. />
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	 Then cut the flesh first, until all of it is finished with a scalpel.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	 And be careful of the eye, so that you do not harm it during the procedure; and let your incision by which you cut [the flesh] be either with a spatula, as we have described in the incision for a fingernail; or with small forceps, with which asebel is collected, according to its form after this chapter.  />  />
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	 When your incision is complete and all the white of the eye has been removed, then fill the eye with crushed salt or sprinkle red powder into it, and similar things from corrosive medicines; and place a cooked egg-white over the eye to secure it from hot inflammation.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	 If some of the white of the eye remains and hot blood prevails in you and you fear a hot inflammation, then leave the eye alone and treat it with that which settles inflammation.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the treatment on it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	 And do similarly with the flesh that happens to be in the eye from this type.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	 However, it is necessary that a stranger should not undertake the treatment of any weak eye from natural or accidental causes by operating with iron, and you should not interfere in any of these operations until you see that this member can bear that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	 ¶ On collecting Sebel (pus) from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter Eighteen
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	 Pus consists of red veins that spread over the eye and hinder its vision; and with the passage of time, they weaken the eye.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	 Therefore, it is necessary for you first to consider whether the eye with pus is strong and has no other illness except for pus; then collect the pus from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And it is necessary that you instruct the patient to place his head on your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	 Then suspend those veins with one or two hooks according to your judgment; and let the hook be of fine wire, as shown in this figure [image not provided], or let there be two hooks on one body, as shown in this figure [image not provided].
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	 Then collect those veins with fine scissors carefully, and wipe away the blood hour by hour until you see those veins removed from the eye, and they dissolve; and be careful not to injure the eye with the ends of the tweezers.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	 And let your operation be at midday before the sun, and be steadfast in your operation very much: so that you do not cut except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	 And when you have cleared it out, then distill into the eye either green or red: so that its sharpness may eat away what remains of the barley seed.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	 But if you are not able to remove all of it at that time, then bandage the eye with something that will alleviate the pain of the eye; and leave it for some days until its pain is relieved: and protect it from a hot abscess; then repeat the same process over it according to the same method until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	 And this is the shape of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	 About reducing a broken nose back to its normal position.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter 19.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	 Doctors call the broken nose a fistula, which they treat with a cautery or with a sharp burning medicine, as was mentioned before in its description.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	 And if it does not heal, then there is no skill in it unless you pierce over the abscess at its origin and draw out all the moisture and pus that is in it until the bone is exposed.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	 Therefore, when the bone is exposed and you see corruption or blackness in it, then scrape it with an instrument whose shape is like this. ■
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	 And its name is "rasp for the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	 Let it be made from Indian iron and let its head be round like a needle, which should be studded with the studs of a file or the studs of a fine rasp; and place it on the corrupted bone. ■ ■ ■
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	 Then turn it between your fingers and press your hand a little until you know that the corruption is scraped off; and do this several times. ■ ■ ■
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	 Then restore the place with dry astringent medicines.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	 If therefore the place consolidates and flesh grows in it, and the course of pus ceases: and it remains for forty days without renewing or becoming inflamed, and no accident occurs in it: then know that it has already been healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	 And if not, then there is no wisdom in it, except to reduce the fistula to the opening of the nose, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	 And it is that you uncover from the bone with a second iron or with a sharp medicine: and when the opening has been uncovered, then take a trepan of this form, its end being iron and triangular: and its handle be a slender pyramid up to the extremity, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	 Then place it over the very opening: and let it be near the tear duct: and extend your hand a little from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	 Then turn your hand with the trepan until it penetrates the opening, and let the patient feel it: because he finds air escaping from it when his hand is placed over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	 Therefore then restore the place with astringent and drying medicines, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	 Therefore when flesh grows and the place hardens, then the matter that was flowing out to the outside returns to the nose: it is therefore easier for the patient.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	 ¶ About the Reduction of an Eye's Prominence.
Caput XX.	 Chapter XX.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	 When an eye protrudes with all of itself and no harm or decrease occurs to the sight, then it is necessary that you release the patient; then phlebotomize him: afterwards place cupping glasses on the neck without scarification, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	 Then place over the eye a plaster made from acacia, and aloe, and frankincense, and sarcocolla.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	 Then bind the eye above with many fine threads on top of the plaster.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	 "And the way to make poultices is this: take soft cloths, many of them, and fold each one into four layers. Make many of these. Then place one on top of another according to the amount needed for the eye. Then bind them together with a hard cloth, tightly.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	 "And repeat the procedure with cupping glasses, using suction without scarification.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	 "Then remove the cupping glasses and leave the eye bandaged day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	 "However, if the ligature becomes loose again, then it must be tied tightly. Then remove the bandage after a day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	 "If you see that the eye has already returned to its normal state, then it is good. If not, then repeat the treatment with plasters, poultices, bandages, and cupping glasses until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	 "Chapter on Incising the Conjunctiva.
Caput XXI.	 "Chapter 21.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	 "When a rupture occurs in the conjunctiva and a lump protrudes from the eyelid like a grain of barley, disfiguring the face, and one wishes to incise it, then the procedure is as follows: insert the needle at the root of the eyelash from below to above.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	 "Then insert another needle with double thread from the lacrimal part and make it penetrate; then leave the first needle in its original position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	 "Then cut the place of the double thread and tie with it the part of the eyelid around the needle; and bind it tightly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	 "Then remove the needle and place a cotton pad soaked in egg white over the eye; and leave it until the thread falls out with the eyelid.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 "Then care for the eye with what strengthens it until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	 "And sometimes the eyelid is bound all around with a ring of cloth until the eye protrudes greatly.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	 Then it should be pierced with a fine needle that reaches to the depth of the eye, and let the moisture of the white run out, and let the eye sink down, and immediately enter; then bind it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	 About the treatment of alcomnatum.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	 This illness, which is called alcomnatum, is nothing but a discharge that accumulates in the eye, similar to water descending, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	 And the way to treat this is by having the patient sit on a prepared or straight seat.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	 Then take his head with your hands on both sides and move it until you see the discharge reach below his eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	 Then it should be fixed and not move downward, and the eye should be released; and the patient should see things as he used to see them; and if it does not move downward, you should know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	 But if the descent of the discharge does not occur as we have said, then have the patient sit between your hands. ️
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	 Then take a fine needle and slightly puncture the skin where the conjunctiva joins with the cornea, near the edge, until the discharge comes out.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 When it comes out, then drip warm water into the eye in which you have mixed honey; or water that has already been boiled with fenugreek and honey. Then treat it with the rest of the remedy until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	 § On the treatment of water descending into the eye, or cataracts.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter 23.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	 Now we have spoken about the types of water according to its division, and which is appropriate for piercing, as the declarative and explanatory speech has stated; then take that same [water] according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then it is necessary for you to have the patient sit between your hands, facing the light, near the sun; and cover his healthy eye, and bind it very tightly; then with your right hand, if the eye in which the water is, is the left eye; or with your left hand, if the eye is the right one. ️
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then take with your right hand the collyrium, if the eye is left: or with your left hand, if the eye is right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	 Then place the tip of the collyrium near the cornea according to the thickness of the radius, in the same whiteness of the eye where the tear duct is smaller; then press the collyrium with force: and you turn your hand with it until it penetrates into the sclera of the eye: and feel that the collyrium has already reached the empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	 And it is necessary that the measure of the journey of the collyrium be to the depth, the measure of the space which is from the pupil until the end of the blackness; and this is the cornea of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	 For you will see them in the very pupil of the eye, because of the clarity of the corneal membrane.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	 Then place the collyrium until it reaches the watery part.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	 Then press it downwards once after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	 If therefore the water immediately comes out, then the patient sees that immediately on which he opens his vision, and the collyrium is in his eye.  ()
Deinde quiescas paululum.	 Then wait a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	 If water comes out, then put it aside a second time, except that the collyrium emerges.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	 When it becomes fixed and does not come out, then remove the collyrium with ease: and you slowly turn your hand.  ()  ()
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	 Then dissolve some of the clear salt crystal in water: and wash the eye with it from within.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	 Then place outside the eye all cotton or wool soaked in rose oil and egg white: and bandage the sound eye with it.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	 But we, and those who are of our time, place on top of it ground barley with egg white.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	 If the collyrium does not obey you at the entrance into the eye because of its hardness, since it is made from humans whose eyes are very hard: then it is necessary that you take a small stick, which is called Albard, and this is what it looks like.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	 So grasp that same membrane with it, and do not thrust your hand through the opening; there is nothing to do but to make a way to the almagda, a subtle place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	 Then introduce the almagda as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	 And at the completion of your work, prepare for the patient a decently made bedchamber in which he may sleep on his back in a dark room; and let him be kept from all movement and coughing; and give him food by which his nature is soothed; and let him not move his head at all to the right or the left.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	 And let the bandage remain according to its arrangement until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	 Then unbind it in that dark room, and test his vision; and make him look at things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	 Then rebinding it until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	 And it is not right to do this at the time of the operation or immediately after the incision; but rather it should be avoided, because water rises quickly through a powerful gaze.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	 But if a hot swelling occurs, then it is necessary to unbind the eye before the seventh day; and treat it with what soothes the swelling until it subsides; then let out its vision, and place on his face a coverlet that regulates his sight under it for several days, while he remains in that dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	 Then let him go forth from the house gradually, and turn to his affairs.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	 And know that a student is not exempted from vision many times; then indeed he may venture upon the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	 And indeed a certain man from those of Alarcos has come to us, who said that at Alarcos an almagda was pierced through which water is sucked out.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	 Truly I have not seen anyone in your land who has done this; nor have I read it in any of the ancient books; and it is possible that it is new. 》
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	 And these are the forms of species from dough, so that it may stand on it who does not know them.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	 Let them be made properly from air: and their extremities should have this same triangular subtlety, and an acute tip.
Formae magda.	 Forms of dough.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	 ¶ On the care for flesh born in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter Twenty-Four.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	 Sometimes in the nose, various kinds of flesh are born, one of which resembles a scorpion with many feet; and from this is cancerous flesh, stone-like, dark in color; and from it is gentle flesh, not dark in color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	 Therefore, in that which is gentle from these fleshes, not deceitful nor cancerous, it is necessary for you to make the patient sit between your hands opposite the ground, and open their nostrils, and throw a hook into those fleshes; then draw them outwards, and cut what you have grasped from them with a thin sharp spatula on one side until you know that all the flesh has now been removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	 But if something of it remains whose cutting is not possible; then scrape that with one of the fine instruments easily, until nothing remains from it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	 But if blood prevails over you, or a hot aposteme occurs; then oppose it with what is necessary: or it is from malignant apostemes, then hurry to cauterize it until the bleeding stops and all the fleshes are removed.  /> But if the patient's nose bleeds frequently and persistently, or there is a severe headache, or fever, or other harmful symptoms appear; then it is necessary for you to stop these, before treating this disease.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	 Then after the incision, vinegar should be poured into the nose, and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	 But if the nose is opened, and moisture comes out of it as far as the palate, then know that he is already healed.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	 But if the moisture does not penetrate as it should, then know that inside there is flesh born in the upper bones of the nose, to which the instrument did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	 Then you should insert a linen thread with some thickness, and tie many knots in it; and place between each knot the length of a finger or less. The patient will then make one end of the thread enter the nose with a bone, or whatever is possible for him to make similar to an awl: and he should pull on his olfactory until it reaches the skull, and exits over his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	 And often boys at school do something similar to this Atom; and it is an easy thing for one who wants to.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	 Then place the two ends of the thread, one end that exits from the nose and the other that remains inside the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	 Then the flesh is cut with a saw along with the knots that are on the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	 Do this until you know that the flesh is now together with the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	 Then remove the thread and place a linen cloth soaked in Egyptian ointment into the nose after washing away the blood. Do this for three days or more until the remaining ointment has completely eaten away the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 Then at the end of the treatment, place a lead tube into the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	 If, however, it needs drying treatment, use this one.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	 For making a head-purge, with which oils and other medicines are distilled into the nose, make this from silver or bronze, similar to a small lamp, open like a shell, and its channel similarly.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	 And if you want to make it as a closed tube, make it like a reed.  />
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	 And the shell of the instrument for making a head-purge should be full and open; it should have a handle at its end with which you hold it when heating oil or whatever liquid substances you wish in it.  />  />  />
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	 And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	 About caring for a broken nose.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter XXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	 A swelling often occurs at the tip of the nose and increases over time, until it becomes unsightly.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	 And because of this, it is necessary that at its first appearance you cut into it and completely remove the whole thing.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	 Then place on the spot either a hot iron or a burning medicine to take its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	 If therefore its incision is delayed until it grows large, then consider whether it is stony, hard, dark in color, and painful; do not touch it with iron because it is a malignant tumor.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	 For many times I have seen that whoever cuts into such a tumor has suffered great harm from it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	 And if the tumor is soft to touch, not dark in color, and you see that it can be cut into entirely, then evacuate the patient and cut into it without fear or dread; and treat the spot with that which dries and contracts until it heals. 😊
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	 About stitching the nose, lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter XXVI.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 Know that when a separation of continuity occurs in one of these cartilages, an operation on it is of little benefit, except in some people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when this happens to someone, you should consider whether it is a recent wound with its own blood; then bring together the edges of the wound with stitches and treat it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	 And if the lips of separation have already separated and each part has become healthy; then it is necessary to scrape off all parts that are visible from their skin until they bleed. 😊
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then bring the two lips together with stitches and tie them; and sprinkle on them powdered blood of a dragon and ground frankincense; and place on these powders a piece of diafinicon plaster and another of the consolidating plasters; and leave it tied for two or three days. 😊 ️
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	 Then dissolve it and replace the medicine; and let it go until the threads are cut off by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Afterwards, take care of him with ointment until he is healed.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	 The method of suturing is to join the continuity with a needle, as we have described in the case of the abdomen, or to join it with thread, as I have taught you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	 ¶ On the Extraction of Lip Nodes.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	 Indeed, many people develop hard lumps inside their lips, similar to grains of barley, and some are smaller while others are larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	 Therefore, you should turn the lip inside out and flatten over each node; then hang it with a hook and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then fill the place after cutting with powdered barley until the blood is cut off.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	 Then wash it with vinegar and scrape the place where the astringency is until the wounds are healed.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	 ¶ On the Incision of Flesh Above the Gum. ➤
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter 28.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	 Often there appears on the gum a growth of flesh which the ancients called abulus.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	 Therefore, you should hang it with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at its root, allowing the pus or blood to run out.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	 Then place on the site powdered barley or other astringent and drying powders.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	 If the flesh returns after treatment, for it often does return, then cut it a second time and cauterize it, for it will not return after cautery.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	 ¶ On the Filing of Teeth with Iron.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter 29.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	 Sometimes there form on the surfaces of teeth, both inside and outside, and between the gums, rough, foul growths which blacken and turn yellow and green until corruption reaches the gum, making the teeth foul.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	 It is necessary that you make the patient sit between your hands and his head on your lap, and shave the tooth and its pulp, in which you see cortices and something similar to sand: until nothing remains of them, and do likewise with the blackness, the greenness, and the yellowness, and other things until they are cleansed.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	 Therefore, if what is in them is removed at the beginning of the reasoning process, that is good; and if not, then you must repeat the reasoning process over them on another day, a second time, and a third time, until finally your effort achieves what you desire.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	 And know that the tooth requires razors of diverse forms and many shapes according to how it is prepared for your operation; therefore, because the razor with which the tooth is shaved from below is different from the razor with which the space between the teeth is shaved, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	 And these shapes of the razors should be prepared for you, as you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	 On the Extraction of Toothache
Caput XXX.	 Chapter XXX
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	 It is necessary to treat the tooth for its pain with all skill and be slow in extracting it.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	 For it is not a matter of replacing its place when extracted: because it is a sublime substance. But when there is no excuse for extracting it, then if the patient is forced to have the tooth extracted, you must firmly secure and establish with yourself the aching tooth.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	 For often the pain deceives the patient and makes him think that it is in the tooth and he extracts it; then the pain does not go away until a weaker tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	 For we have already seen this in the practice of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	 Therefore, when the aching tooth itself is firmly established with you, then it is necessary that you scarify around the tooth with a spatula, on which there is some power, until the gum is dissolved from every side; then move the tooth gently with your fingers or with fine forceps little by little until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	 Then place large forceps in a good position on it, and hold the patient's head between your knees so that you have held it well enough that it does not move; then draw the tooth straight, so that you do not break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If it does not come out, then take one of those instruments and insert it beneath it from all sides with ease, and try to move it, as you did first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	 If the tooth is perforated or corroded, then you must fill that hole with cloth; and tie it with a fine string, so that it does not break at the time of your squeezing on top of it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	 And you must act very carefully with scarification all around the gums from every side greatly.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	 And be strong so that you do not break it, and a part of it remains, and returns upon the patient with greater evil than his first pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	 And beware of doing what ignorant bleeders do out of haste and their own boldness in removing it, besides administering that which we have narrated.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	 For many times they cause great diseases to befall men, which are very difficult to break and all or some of its roots remain; or that they extract it with some bones of the jaw, as we have often witnessed this.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	 Then let it be rinsed after its extraction with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	 If bleeding occurs from the site (for this often happens), then take some of zegi and fill the site with it; and if not, cauterize it if zegi does not benefit you.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	 The tips of the fine forceps with which the tooth is first moved should be long, and have a short, thick handle so that they do not bend when pressed on the tooth with them; they should be like you see with thick handles, until when you squeeze with them, they do not give way to themselves or bend; they should have short tips, and be made of Indian iron or well-made steel, straight at the tips; and in their tips there should be teeth, some fitting into others, and binding with a decent, strong constriction.  />
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	 And sometimes they become like the beak of a bird called a stork, and are very narrow.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	 About the extraction of teeth, and the removal of broken jawbones.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	 When something remains after the extraction of a broken tooth, then you should place a cotton pad with butter on it for one day or two days until the area softens; then introduce to it tweezers or forceps whose tips resemble the beak of a bird called a stork.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	 This is the form of forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	 Let their tips be made like a file within, or like a chisel.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not yield to you with these forceps, then you should make an incision on the root and expose all the flesh; then introduce a small lever whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	 Let it be short of tip, somewhat thick; and let it not be brittle, so that it does not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	 If the root comes out with it, that is good; and if not, you must help with these other instruments whose forms are these. ¶ Adhuc alii instrumenti faciuntur de ligno, et non franguntur.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	 The form of the first is triangular at the tip, in which there is a certain thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	 The form is a thin triangular tip.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	 Also help with this instrument having two branches, whose form is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	 And with the other instruments and tools that have been mentioned earlier regarding teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	 Also help with this instrument that resembles a large hook of this form, having a twisted triangular tip with some thickness so it does not break; and let it be not brittle.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	 And know that the instruments of teeth are many; and likewise the other instruments are not counted, and an expert craftsman, subtle in his art, finds by himself an instrument according to what the operation and the illnesses themselves indicate.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	 Because of the variety of kinds of diseases about which the ancients did not speak of instruments.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	 If, however, the bone is broken from the jaw or other bones of the mouth, or if it becomes rotten; then explore over it in its place with what suits it from the instruments and forceps which I mentioned for root extraction, and help with this hook, whose shape is this:
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	 Let there be in it something thick gradually, so that the bone may be held or grasped with it, and not slip away, until the bone comes out; and restore the place with suitable medicines for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 But if there is only a small rottenness in the bone, then scrape it from its rottenness, and care for it, until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	 About the binding of protruding teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter 32.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	 When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, the form becomes ugly through that; and especially when this happens to women and girls, namely whores.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	 Therefore, you should consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 For if a tooth is born after another tooth and is not placed, or its binding or filing is possible; then extract it. And if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this instrument, whose form is this:
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	 It is similar to a small beak and is made from Indian iron, with a very sharp tip.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	 And let your cut, by which you cut it, be over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, so that another tooth may not be disturbed.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	 But if it is protruding and ready for filing; then file it with an Indian file, whose form is this: ›
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	 It should be all of Indian iron, and its handle of very small points, as the file with which needles are made; with which the tooth is filed little by little over many days with ease, so that the tooth may not be disturbed or fall out; then smooth it, finally scrape it with certain scrapers.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	 If it is a tooth, from which a piece breaks off and injures the tongue, then it must be filed evenly until the roughness of that break is removed, leveled, and smoothed so that it no longer injures the tongue or corrupts speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	 Concerning the extraction of teeth using golden threads.
Caput XXXIII.	 Chapter 33
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	 When a concussion or injury occurs to the front teeth from a blow or accident, and the patient cannot bite down on what they are eating so that it does not fall out, and you have treated them with astringent medicines but the treatment has not been effective, then there is a method for securing them using a golden thread. Because silver turns green and rots after several days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	 And the thread should be of medium thinness and thickness according to the size between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	 And the manner of this extraction is as follows: take a thread and insert its double between two healthy teeth; then weave it with both ends of the thread between the loose teeth, whether one or several, until you reach with the weaving to the other healthy tooth on the opposite side.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	 Then repeat the weaving back to where you started; and bind with finesse and wisdom until it does not move at all; and let your binding of the thread be near the roots of the teeth, so that it does not slip out.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	 Then cut off the superfluous ends of the thread with scissors; and join them together and turn them back with a probe; and hide them between a healthy tooth and a loose tooth, so that they do not injure the tongue; then let it remain thus bound until it heals.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	 But if it loosens or breaks, bind them again with another thread, and they will remain secure in this manner for the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	 And this is the form of the teeth, and the figure of the extraction of two healthy teeth and two loose teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	 And sometimes it happens that one tooth or two return to their original places after the accident, and are retained as we have described, and remain there; and this is done only by an skilled craftsman, wise and experienced.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	 And sometimes a bone from an ox is prepared; and it is made into the shape of a tooth, and placed in its position, by which the tooth is supported and fastened, as we have said; and it remains and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	 Concerning the cutting of the ligament that occurs beneath the tongue, which prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	 Sometimes this ligament that occurs beneath the tongue is natural, present from birth, or it may be acquired, resulting from an old healed wound.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	 And the procedure is to open the patient's mouth wide and lift up their tongue; then cut through that nerve-like ligament across its width until the tongue is freed from its constriction.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	 But if there is something hard and knotted in it, and it is due to an old healed wound, then insert a hook into it and cut through its width until you reach the ligament and free the knot. ›
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And be careful not to create a deep cut in the flesh, lest you cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	 Then wash the site of the incision with rose water or vinegar or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	 Then place a linen cloth under the tongue for the patient to hold every night, so that it does not heal again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	 But if bleeding occurs, then apply powdered alum to the site.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 But if the bleeding is too much for you to manage, then cauterize the site with a suitable cautery iron; then treat it with the usual care until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	 Of the extraction of a salivary gland that forms under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	 Sometimes an abscess occurs under the tongue that resembles a small frog, preventing the tongue from performing its natural function; and perhaps it grows so large that it fills the mouth.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	 And the procedure is to open the mouth of the patient in sunlight and examine the abscess.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	 If you see that it is dark or black in color, hard, and the patient cannot feel it, then do not touch it, because it is a cancer.  
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	 And if it is inclined towards whiteness and has moisture, then place a hook into it, and cut it with a thin scalpel, and free it from all parts.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	 If blood overcomes you during your procedure, then place crushed zea on it until the bleeding stops; then return to your procedure until you extract it with all of its contents.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then wash it with vinegar and salt, and care for it with the remaining appropriate treatment until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	 ¶ Of the treatment of an abscess in both tonsils.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	 Sometimes abscesses occur between the throat and the glands, which are similar to glands that appear externally; they are called tonsils. If you treat them with what we have said about incision and they do not heal, then consider them.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	 If the abscess is hard, dark in color, and has little sensation, then do not touch it with an iron instrument.   
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	 And if it is red in color and its base is thick, then do not touch it even with an iron instrument, fearing a flow of blood; rather, leave it until it matures.      
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	 And then either you will pierce it or it will burst on its own.      
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	 And if it is of white color and round, and its root is fine: then it should be cut.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 And the operation on it is this, that you should consider before its operation, if the aposteme becomes quiet after a complete quietude, or is diminished by some diminution: then indeed make the sick person sit before the sun, and his head be in your lap; and open his mouth, and let the servant receive between his hands, and press down his tongue below with an instrument, of which this is the shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	 Let it be made of silver or bronze, which should be as fine as a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	 So when you press with it the tongue and the aposteme is shown to you, and your sight falls on it: then take a hook, and insert it into the tonsil, and draw it outwards as much as you can, except that you should also pull some of its tunics with it.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	 Then cut it with an instrument, the shape of which is as follows.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	 It resembles scissors; however its extremities should be curved, so that the opening of each is directly against the other's edge. Therefore ensure that it is made of iron of Indus, or steel tempered by immersion in vinegar.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	 But if this instrument is not present, then cut it with a scalpel, the shape of which is as follows.  /> It resembles a knife, however its extremity should be sharpened on both sides.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	 Let it be sharp on one side and not sharp on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	 And after you have cut one tonsil, cut the other according to this same form of incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	 Then after the incision, let the sick person rinse with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 But if bleeding occurs, let him rinse with water in which the bark of oak apples or myrtle leaves and similar astringents have been boiled, until the flow of blood is stopped; then treat him until he is cured.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	 And sometimes there arise on the throat other abscesses besides the two tonsils.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	 Therefore, cut those according to what I said about cutting the two tonsils evenly.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	 And indeed I myself have already treated a woman for an abscess that had arisen in her throat, which was drawing toward blackening, scarcely any sensation remained, and it had nearly closed the throat: and the woman was breathing with difficulty, and it had already prevented her from eating food and drinking water; and she had almost reached death if she had remained for one day or two.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	 And the abscess had risen so much that it had sent forth two branches, until they came out through both nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	 Therefore I hastened and inserted a hook into one of them.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	 Then I pulled it, and with it was drawn out a large piece.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	 Then I cut off the piece where it had been caught at the nostril opening.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	 Then I did the same to what came out of the other nostril opening.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	 Then I opened her mouth and pressed down on her tongue; and then I inserted a hook into the abscess itself; then I cut off part of it, and only a little blood flowed out. Therefore the woman's throat was healed, and she immediately began to drink water, and then took food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	 I did not stop cutting from that abscess many times over a long period; and the abscess would come forth in place of what I had cut, until it was stretched out too much along with her.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	 Therefore, I incised and cauterized the abscess in the throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	 It stopped from growing; then I left her side, and I do not know what God did with her after that.  /> 120.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	 ¶ About the incision of an abscess on the lip.
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter 37
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	 When the catarrh descends to the mouth and forms a swelling that is long, it is called "perpendicular." And if it is thick and round at the bottom, it is called an "uvula.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	 When it is treated with what we have said regarding division, and the treatment does not help, and you see that the hot swelling has quieted from it, and it is subtle, then you should cut into it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	 And if from it a round swelling has formed, which does not have length, and is red or dark-colored or black, and does not have sensation, then you should avoid cutting into it.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	 For in this there is danger for the patient.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	 Therefore, when you see it according to the manner that I have said concerning its whiteness and length, make the patient sit before the sun; then press his tongue with the instrument whose description has preceded. Afterwards, insert a hook into the uvula and draw it down; then cut it with one of the two instruments which I have mentioned for the incision of the two tonsils. ︎
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	 And you should not cut from it except that which is added beyond the natural limit without additional growth.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	 For if you cut more than this, you will harm the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	 After the incision, use what we have described for the incision of the two tonsils; and care for it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	 But if the patient is frightened by the incision, then you should use ingenuity in cauterizing it without fear or dread.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 And the method of cautery for it is not except with sharp water, and this is that you place the patient's head on your lap. ︎ ︎ ︎
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	 Then press his tongue with the instrument which I have mentioned.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	 Then take from the water which I have mentioned to you in the chapter on cautery and make a cup not yet extinguished with it, and place it not too thick nor too thin, and fill with it the concavity of this instrument, whose form is thus.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	 Let there be a depression at its end where the medicine is placed, like the hollow of a spoon.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	 And put the instrument with the medicine on the wound itself: and let the sick person lie on their side, so that the saliva runs out of their mouth from the internal medicine, so that nothing from it descends into the throat and harms them.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	 Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	 And you should do this on the wound for half an hour until you see it become blackened and the bite of the medicine has calmed down.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	 And if you wish to use a bandage, wrap it around the end of the spoon and pour the medicine over the bandage, then insert the spoon with the bandage into the wound until the bandage sticks to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	 Do this many times until you achieve what you want from the cautery of the wound.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	 Then leave it; for it will dry up and fall off after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	 If you need to renew the medicine, renew it; and after cauterization, clean around the wound with a bandage soaked in butter, and cleanse it with what remains of the medicine around it; and then rinse with cold water.  />
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	 And let it be scraped externally with ointments, and internally with gargles, until it heals.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	 Therefore, this method of treatment is more wholesome than cutting and further from danger.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	 And sometimes the wound is also cured with something finer than cautery and cutting; for it is cured with fumigation, in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	 Take calament, hyssop, oregano, rue, saffron, chamomile, and southernwood, and similar herbs; and gather all of them or some of them in a pot and let them be soaked with vinegar and boiled; and the pot should be well daubed with clay; and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, over which should be placed a concave instrument in this way.  />  />  />
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	 Let it be made of silver or copper, and its tip, where the seed is, should be inserted into the mouth of the patient until the vapor rises to the top over the tube, until the mouth becomes very dark.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	 Then repeat this many times on the same spot until it dries out.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	 And be careful not to perform this treatment at the beginning of the abscess formation.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	 For it often increases the swelling, and you should not do this unless the abscess is cooled down.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	 But if this instrument is not available to you, then take a reed and put the shell of an egg on its tip so that the patient's mouth does not burn, because the eggshell prevents the vapor from burning the mouth, and this is a good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	 ¶ On extracting thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	 Often a bone or a fishbone gets stuck in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	 Therefore, you should extract whatever is visible from the throat after pressing the tongue with an instrument against the sun, and it will be revealed to you what is inside the throat. ➤
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	 And whatever does not appear and is hidden in the throat, you must make the patient vomit before the food settles in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	 For perhaps the object will come out with the vomit.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	 Or the patient should swallow a piece of nap, or a lettuce root, or a dry biscuit; or he should take a small piece of soft sponge, tie it on a string, and then swallow it. ➤
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	 When it reaches the place where the bone or thorn is, it will be pulled out, and then it will come out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	 If it does not come out with what we have mentioned, then use an instrument made of lead in this manner. ➤ ➤
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	 It should be somewhat thicker than the radius and have a curve at its tip, which it can easily insert into its throat; and it should have its head raised upward.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	 And let it be careful not to touch its epiglottis, lest coughing occur; and let it expel with it bone, or spine, or let the physician insert his hand into it.
