Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	 Place a stick or board under the bone below in an orderly manner, because when you do that, it will not prevent the sawing of the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	 And it is necessary that the sawing be done on the corrupted place for a short while, so that corruption does not befall the concavity of the bone; and so that it does not become apparent to the senses in its appearance, compelling another part to be sawed instead.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	 If the bone is corrupted and not prominent, but rather one of its parts is connected to another part, and the corruption is in the middle or in a part of it, then expose all the flesh from every part completely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	 Then place a stick below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	 Then saw it from the first part where the corruption is until the sawing continues to the other side; and let the sawing be according to the length of the corruption for a short while, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	 But if the corruption is at a joint, cut the corrupted joint and saw the bone where it continues on the other side.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	 But if the corruption is at a continuation of two joints, then there is no skill required except scraping.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	 But if the corruption is in the comb of the hand or the comb of the foot, then the matter in it is very difficult.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	 Truly, you must examine how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	 And scrape it and clean it in whatever way is possible for you and with whatever skill you can manage, when a vein or nerve does not stand in your way.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	 And know that there are many instruments and saws for cutting these bones according to the position of the bones, their preparation, their thickness or thinness, their size or smallness, their hardness or softness. 》
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	 Therefore, you should prepare an appropriate tool for each type of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	 And know that these operations indicate to you the form of the tool you need when your study is prolonged.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	 And the knowledge of the methods of this art is evidence of the methods of illnesses, for then you will find through yourself that which is suitable for each from the tools for every ailment.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	 And I confirm to you at the end of this chapter the number of tools, which you will set as examples on which you will operate, and the test by which you will experiment on others. 》
Forma Serrae.	 Shape of the Saw
Forma alterius Serrae.	 The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 The shape of yet another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	 The shape of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	 This form of the saw is depicted, let it be made elegantly.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	 Its handle should be curved, its edge made of iron, and its grip from boxwood, let it be elegantly made in a pyramidal shape.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	 The form of the scissors for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	 Let the head of this scissors be according to the form of the head of a star-shaped nail, and its points according to the form of the points of a spindle whorl.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	 And it is not suitable except for when the heads of joints are rubbed with it, when they become corrupt or when the mouth is wide and large.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	 The form of the larger scissors. 》
Forma medii Rasorii.	 The shape of the medium scissors.
Forma Rasorii lati.	 The shape of the broad scissors.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	 The form of the scissors which has a hollow.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	 The shape of another fine scissors. 》 》 》 》
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	 The shape of another curved-tipped scissors.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 The shape of a small and fine-pointed pair of scissors.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 The form of the scissors with which bones are cut.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also, the form and that of a large pair of scissors.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 This resembles a rib, and its end is like a saw: it appears in many places due to the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 The shape of the scalpel fits the nature of what has been penetrated by the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its end is triangular and sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	 It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And likewise, all that we have said must be made from scalpels, incisors, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 ¶ On the incision of limbs and sawing of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Chapter 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 Limbs become putrid either due to an external cause or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 When you have treated that corruption with medical treatment and it does not help, and you see the corruption spreading to the limb without any cause; then you must incise that limb up to where the corruption reaches, so that the patient may be saved from death or from a greater defect of the limb.  />
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign of this is that the limb becomes blackened until it stinks; whether fire has burned it or it has become putrid after the blackening. Until that putrefaction reaches what follows the limb and spreads throughout the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Therefore hasten with its incision, and likewise if the cause of the corruption is from the bite of some venomous things, such as a sea-scorpion, viper, asp, or similar.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If the corruption or bite is on the tip of a finger, then cut off the finger and do not leave any space for the corruption to spread to the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And likewise if it occurs on the hand, then cut it off from the root of the wrist, and do not leave any space for the corruption to spread until it reaches the wrist.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it invades that part, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If corruption passes through and you see it about a foot long: then in that is the death of the sick person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And to administer beyond that from treatment is the quantity of strength.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And likewise do for the foot, when corruption invades a toe, then cut it off at one of the joints; and if it reaches the sole of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 But if it rises to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 And if corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill [to save it], except dismissal and leaving the patient to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 And the way of cutting off a limb or sawing it is to tie a ligature below where you wish to cut: and tie another ligature above that place. 》 》 》
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And let the assistant stretch one ligature downwards; and let the other assistant stretch the upper ligature upwards.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligatures with a wide spatula until all the flesh is laid bare. 》 》 》 》 》 》
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then let it be cut or sawed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth from all sides so that the saw does not touch the healthy place; and a secondary injury may occur to the patient, and a hot abscess [may form].
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 But if bleeding occurs inside while you work, then quickly cauterize the place; or put on it certain powders that cut off the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your treatment until it is complete. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligature and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you what happened to a man on his foot, this same thing that I am telling you about. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 What this means is: "This is because a blackening occurred in his foot due to the burning that resembles fire's burning; and that corruption first affected his toe until it began to affect the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 Therefore, the man cut himself after he saw that the corruption had fallen on his member with great force, which he felt through pain and burning; and it fell upon him at the joint, and he was cured.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long time had passed, that same corruption occurred in his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 So he came to me, and I tried to cure that excess with what I applied on his hand from medicines after cleansing his body; and the excess did not go away, but began to spread into another finger until the corruption affected the whole hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 He then called for me to cut off his hand; and I refused, hoping that from me the excess would be cured; and I also feared that he might die if his hand were amputated.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Because the man's strength was greater than his condition.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 After he lost hope in me, he returned to his homeland; and I heard from him that he cut off his hand entirely; and he was cured.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I have not told this story except to be of help for what falls under this type of illness; and that it may be understood and acted upon accordingly.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 § On the Treatment of Gout and the Preparation of Purgatives with Medicines.
Caput XC.	 Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When an abscess occurs in some fleshy members and the space of the abscess is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus; then it bursts or is perforated, and what is in it exits with the pus, and there remains a hollow place as if it were a vessel; and the skin above it is like a thin cloth that has been worn away: and the corruption does not reach its end, nor does it press into a bone, nor into a nerve, nor into a ligament; then it deserves to be called Sinus; and it is not called Fistula. However, if its space is prolonged until it presses into one of these members, then it is called Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And its treatment is to cut the skin completely as it rolls: and especially when it has been made thin, and turned into cloth: and you can be confident that it will not adhere to the place, due to its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 But if you hope that the skin will adhere and that this final corruption does not follow: and if there is thickness in the flesh of the skin, then treat it with an enema: and consider it towards the cavity.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 Then if it is large, and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor: then enema it with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and quicklime, the parts being equal, combined in a vessel: and boil them over fire until the medicine turns red: and reaches the consistency of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take as much of it as you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and enema the cavity with it: and close its opening, and leave the medicine in it for the space of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then withdraw it with an expression: do this every day until the cavity is cleansed and the foul odor is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And sometimes it should be enemaed with water of ashes, when this medicine is not available to you: and it is that you take ashes from grapevine wood or ashes from holm oak wood: and pour water over them.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then strain it, and enema with it until you are confident that the cavity has been washed out.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine or ash water, then enema it with water and honey, in which some crushed quicklime has already been mixed.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or enema it with honey and wine mixed together, because of the property of honey, which cleanses and washes: and wine makes the cavity adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you do that several times and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has been removed, then irrigate it with what makes flesh grow therein.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And it is necessary to take some of the plaster called diafinicon; dissolve it with rose oil and stiptic wine; or irrigate it with certain medicines and other ointments whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 But if the orifice of the sinus is narrow and does not accept the cannula for irrigation, then briefly enlarge it with an iron instrument; or place in it a wick wrapped in Egyptian ointment, or in basilicum ointment, until it is dilated.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the orifice is also wide, then gather its lips with a stitch; and let out from it the quantity that can enter without increasing the irrigation.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the orifice from which the pus flows is raised higher; then cut it in a lower place within it, so that the pus may flow downward; for when the pus is constricted in the depths of the sinus, it prevents flesh from growing therein.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 But if it is not possible for you to cut the sinus lower as you wish; then try to prepare the member with a preparation that allows the pus to flow easily, according to what is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try that nothing at all from the pus is retained therein; and take healing ointments which are placed on the sign, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 And spread them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And let the cloth be of such quantity that it covers the entire sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors a hole directly into the orifice of the sinus, slightly larger than the orifice of the sinus itself.  />
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread over another cloth some of the soft ointments according to the size of the hole; and place it on top with a long-lasting position far from the opening of the sinus, so that the exit of pus from it may be alleviated; and do not remove the large cloth except after several days, once a day.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 But the one that is over the opening of the sinus is the one you remove every hour so that what accumulates in it may exit; and so you may know whether that which runs out of it is much or little: or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And with this, again consider the location of its sinus, whether its master feels pain there or whether there is no pain there and whether it has a swelling there or does not have a swelling there.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 Therefore, when your treatment is extended in this manner and you see the matter that comes out over the opening of the sinus, then know that the sinus is already adhering or approaching adhesion; therefore release it in the morning or on the third day. And when you release the wound, then change another cloth and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 But if after a long time a thin pus comes out of the sinus, then do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching; since among men there are some who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds and there are those who act contrary to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	 But if after many days undigested pus comes out of the sinus, then know that the sinus is not adhering.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If therefore the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its process is prolonged; then in drying medicines, let the doctors make them so that they are humid in their substance and dry in their power; such as the ointment dyafinicon, when a superabundance of zegi is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the last chapter to be cured is this: take diaphanic ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, then sprinkle on it ancient wine equal in substance to itself.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then mix it with that, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And now make something similar to this procedure when you do not have diaphanic ointment: take honey and cook it until it thickens, then use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or take myrrh, aloe, and frankincense: grind all of them together and sprinkle the powder over honey while it is on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then spread it on a cloth and tie it over the ulcer; and smear it with the honey you cooked until it thickens; and sprinkle powdered spices on it, and place another cloth over it, and tie it on.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And sometimes it is given in that long-stemmed birthwort, and the root of celestial lily, which is lily; and flour of herb, and centaury.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them either simply or compounded; grind them and sift them; and sprinkle the powder on the honey I mentioned, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 But if the ulcer is prolonged and not cured by this treatment, then know that there is corruption at its depth; or it has already made an impression on the bones, or other hard parts of the body, or ligaments; then cure it with the treatment for fistulas as was previously mentioned.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 § On the care for whitlow and a crushed nail, and an added finger incision and section.
Caput XCI.	 Chapter 90.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Whitlow is an abscess that arises under the thumbnail of the hand or foot, and perhaps it may arise in other fingers as well.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 So when its condition is prolonged and its care is neglected, it becomes an abscess with hot inflammation; or it becomes corrupt and emits pus until it erodes the root of the nail; and perhaps the corruption affects the whole nail; and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone so that there is a foul odor; and the end of the finger becomes swollen, and its color becomes dark. 》
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When therefore you cure it with what we have said in division, and your treatment does not help, then you should cut off with a knife all the remaining overgrowth from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Then cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 For cautery is very healing.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 But if the bone is healthy and the nail is also healthy, and the nail's additions are already pressing into the flesh within, and they begin to sting it and harm it: then you should place a thin wire under the corner of the nail that is stinging the flesh, and push it upward; and cut off that part of the flesh with ease, and put on what remains of the flesh from medicines that burn and corrode until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 But if the corruption has already penetrated into the bone, then you must cut out that bone and remove it; for it will never heal as long as there is a corrupted bone within it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 But if you see the corrosion and corruption spreading into the finger, then cut it off at one of its joints, as was previously mentioned for its remembrance.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 But if there is injury or bruising of the nail and it causes intense pain, then you should bleed the patient first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with a sharp blade across its width from top to bottom as needed.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And be careful that the cut does not reach the flesh beneath the nail, for by doing so you will cause intense pain to the patient and it will lead to the addition of new flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then treat the area with something that eases the pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 But an additional finger that is born in the hands of some people is perhaps entirely fleshy; and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps a nail grows on it; and sometimes its birth occurs at the root of a joint, or it is born in some of the finger's joints. ">
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 That which is born at certain nodes of the finger does not move; and that which is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 Therefore, the incision of that which comes from it is easy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 Which is, as you cut it at its root with a wide spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 However, the treatment of that whose birth is at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore, refrain from incising it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 But in that which is born in the finger at the last of the nodes, then you should cut its flesh with a round incision to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then saw the bone with one of those saws that fits it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 However, the stiffening that occurs between fingers often happens either from birth, that is, it is born with it, or from the stiffening of a wound, or from burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, it is necessary to cut away that stiffness until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place between them bandages or cloths soaked in rose oil, so that they do not quickly stiffen again, and separate them; or place between them a thin sheet of lead until the place consolidates as it should be.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if stiffness occurs between some fingers with the palm, then cut away that stiffness according to how it is prepared and appropriate for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 ¶ On the Incision of Birthmarks.
Caput XCII.	 Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 Birthmarks are swollen, thick veins filled with melancholic humors that occur in many parts of the body; and their outcome is most common in the legs, especially in the legs of travelers, workers, and those who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 You should therefore administer purging of the body with black bile frequently and strongly.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then perform bloodletting on the patient from a basilic vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 However, their treatment with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One of them is that they are cut and black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And the other method is that a vein is elevated and the entire thing is drawn out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Its cutting is according to this manner.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 Soak the leg first with very warm water until the thick, muddy blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then bind the patient's leg from the upper part of their thigh to the lower part of the knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein in one place, or two, or three, with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then elevate, that is, draw the blood into your hand from the lower part of the leg upwards, and first the phlebotomist should bleed the patient.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail along with the lower part until an amount of blood that you see is sufficient and that the strength of the patient can bear comes out.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Afterwards bind it, and instruct the patient to abstain from foods that generate black bile, and repeat evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are filled and it harms the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 Its elevation is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Shave the patient's leg if it has many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then place the patient in a bath, or soak the leg in hot water until it turns red and the veins become engorged, or have them exercise strongly if there is no available bath, until the limb becomes warm.  />
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then cut the skin along the length of the vein's incision, or at its end near the knee, or at its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with hooks, and strip the vein from every part until it becomes perceptible to the senses; and at its appearance you see that it turns red to black.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it comes out of the skin, you see that it is white like a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then introduce under it a rod, until when it is lifted and comes out of the skin; suspend it with a blind hook, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then cut another incision near that incision by three fingers' breadth.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then strip the skin from above the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then lift it with rods as you did before, and suspend it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then cut another incision, or more incisions, if you need that.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then lift it and cut the last incision at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then pull it out to the incision that is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 And do this until you pull it out of the higher incision, or all the incisions, until it comes out completely; then cut it off.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 But if it does not obey you in being pulled out and lifted; then introduce a needle with a strong double thread, and tie it, and pull it out; or insert a rod under it: and turn your hand to every part until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And beware that it is not cut.  /> If you can't extract the vein as described above, use a strong needle with double thread and tie it around the vein. Then pull it out gently. Alternatively, insert a rod under the vein and turn your hand in all directions until the vein comes out completely. Be careful not to cut the vein during this process.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it will be very difficult for you to lift it up, and a great harm will come upon the patient from that.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when you have pulled it out completely; then place on the wound site a wool cloth soaked in rose oil or oil; and care for him until he is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If the tendon is contracted and has a twist such that it winds around parts, and is not straight as we said before: then you should cut through it at every point of its twist and places of its winding.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then suspend it with hooks until you raise the whole thing: and be careful not to cut a vein or cause injury at your cut, for it will be difficult for you to raise or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Therefore, be wise.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The Shape of the Incision by Which a Tendon is Treated.
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The Shape of the Blind Stitch.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It does not have a curve like the other stitches, nor does it have an acute tip so as not to injure a vein; and it is of thick, flexible material, gentle: because if it were thin, it would cut through the vein with its thinness; rather, let there be some excess thickness in it, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 On the Extraction of a Vein from the Leg.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is found in the legs in hot countries, such as Alsace and the Arab lands, and in dry, hot countries of little fertility, that is, where neither grass nor trees grow.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it occurs in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 And its generation is from the corruption that occurs under the skin, just like the corruption that occurs within the body with snakes and roundworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And the sign of the beginning of this vein's occurrence is that a severe swelling occurs in the leg.  />
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then the place becomes blistered.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein begins to come out from that place of blistering, like a root of a plant or an animal.  />  />
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 Therefore, when its end appears, then you should wrap a piece of lead around it, weighing from one and a half drams to two and a quarter drams, and tie it; and let the hanging lead be suspended from the leg.  />
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something comes out from it to the outside, wrap it in lead and tie it off.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it is extended greatly, then cut off a part of it, and wrap up the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 And do not cut it off completely until it has come out entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 For if you cut it, it contracts and goes into the flesh, causing an abscess and rotting in that place, and a bad sore.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it is necessary that it be gently handled and drawn out little by little until it comes out completely from its end, and nothing remains of it in the body; and this vein, in some people, comes out to a length of five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has come to me because it came out of a man from twenty palms.  />
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 But if it is cut during your treatment, then insert a rod through its opening and pierce it with a long hole, along with the body, until everything that is in it from matter is evacuated; and apply rotting of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then treat him with the care for abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot or in the foot itself; and many openings occur on it, and a branch comes out from each opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore treat it as we said in the division, and with what was stated before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 ¶ On the cutting of worms generated under the skin, which is called the disease of cows.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This disease is named in a certain land among us the cow's disease, because it often happens to cows, and it is a small worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.  />  />
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it goes through the whole body, ascending and descending; and it is perceived by sense during its motion from member to member, until it bursts into whatever place it bursts on the skin and comes out.  />  />  />
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 "And its generation is from the putrefaction of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 "Just as worms and snakes, that is, leeches and roundworms, occur in the stomach.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 "And it is feared because of its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 "Because when it moves through the body and is raised to the head and reaches that place, then perhaps it opens there and exits, destroying the eye; and this often happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 "Therefore, when you wish to cure it and remove it, this can only be done during its movement and appearance to the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 "It is therefore necessary that you tie what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 "Then cut above it and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 "But if it has penetrated deeply into the flesh and you do not find it, then place a cautery with fire on the spot until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 "And what is more to be feared is its corruption, by which it corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 "But if you see that it has already reached the head near the eye, then tie a good ligature around the eyebrow below it.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 "Then cut above it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 "And the patient should use purification of his body with medicines that dissolve bad, putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 "And he should avoid foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 "Concerning the incision for Nakir's disease.
Caput XCV.	 "Chapter 95
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 "This illness is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in certain members; then it changes from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 "And I myself have already seen it, as I am now telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 "I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 "And she revealed her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the cord of the arm vein." ‌
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And after one hour had passed, I saw a swelling advancing with a torch, just like a worm, ascending to his shoulder more quickly than it possibly could be: as if it were living silver, running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 Therefore the pain retreated from that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 Then I waited one hour, and it ran into the rest of the body, until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then he told me that it was revolving throughout his whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 Therefore I marveled at the speed of its change from member to member.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And indeed, before that, I had not seen this illness with my own eyes in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 However, I have seen many who find pain changing from member to member; and I did not see it with my own eyes as I saw it in the woman. 》
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that is so unless it is because the woman was one of those who are from dry-bodied people with exposed veins; therefore it appears to the senses that the gaseousness has been changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that they do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 When therefore you wish to cure it and the patient feels that pain, then if it is appearing to your eye as we have said, then bind swiftly above it and below it; and cut above it until the gaseousness emerges constricted; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If however you do not see it with your own eyes, then treat him with a body purge and with that which expels gaseousness, and mixes them with foul pills and pills of celery seed and the like.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 On the Extraction of Arrows
Caput XCVI.	 Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are distinguished by their various types and the places where they strike the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 For there is a diversity among them, since some have large tips and others small ones; some are hollow, and others blunt.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And among them are those that have three points.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And among them are those with tongues (barbs). )))
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And among them are those with stars (fletchings).
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 But those that fall according to the members where they strike are of two kinds. )))
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 For the members are either from the main hollow organs, such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidney, intestines, bladder, and similar ones. ))) )))) )))
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When, therefore, it falls into one of these organs and the signs of death, which I will tell you about later, appear to you, then you must avoid extracting that arrow from them, for death follows the person in whom it is found in many cases.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 But when these bad signs do not appear to you and the arrow is not hidden deep within the organ, then extract it and care for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 For the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and pierces through the bone and exits above the brain are: because a severe headache occurs from it, along with blindness, dizziness, redness in the eyes, swelling, redness of the tongue, spasms, confusion of the mind, and vomiting of bile. ))) ))) ))))))
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And perhaps blood may exit from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And perhaps speech is cut off and the voice is destroyed. )))
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And from the place of the wound a white moisture like boiled starch exits. ))) )))
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And it comes out of it resembling wateriness of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment and extract the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of the arrow when it falls into the heart are that it is near the left nipple and the person feels with it as if it were fixed in a hard substance, not an empty one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps there is a movement of the arrow similar to the movement of the pulse, and black blood runs from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And it is followed by coldness of the extremities, cold sweat, and fainting spells.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Know therefore that death has certainly come.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 And the sign of an arrow that has wounded the lung is the issuing of frothy blood from the wound; and the veins that follow the neck swell up, and the color of the patient changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And he breathes out a large, deep breath, and seeks cold air to breathe in.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If the arrow falls into the diaphragm, which is in the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and there is a great panting with intense pain, along with sighing; and all the limbs of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if the arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out of the wound with it.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if the arrow falls into the belly and is fixed there, then something comes out of the wound - either feces, or a piece of intestine that has already been torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 There is therefore no hope in treating it or in extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If the arrow falls into the bladder and urine comes out, and something protrudes to the outside, and the pain is stronger upon the patient, then know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The remaining limbs, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and shoulder blade, and arm, and scapula of the back, and collarbone, and hip, and leg, and similar members are healed in many ways when the arrow does not find an artery or a nerve; and the arrow is not poisoned.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you that I have seen these arrows, so that you may indicate through it the treatment for yourself.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 What happened was that a certain man had an arrow strike his tear duct at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 So I removed it from the other side, from under his ear's fat: and he was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 And I removed another arrow from a Jew that had struck him under his lower eyelid in the eye's fat: and the arrow was already hidden, and I only got out of it a small part of its end, to which its wood adhered: and the arrow was large for Turkish bows, with soft iron, in which there are no barbs.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 So the Jew was cured, and no misfortune befell his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I removed another arrow from a Christian's throat.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 And it was an Arabic arrow, and that is the kind with barbs.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 So I cut above it between two guides [muscles]: and it was already sunk into his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 So I made myself fine with it, until I removed it: and the Christian was cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And I removed another arrow from a man that had struck him in his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed and nothing about his condition changed, I cut above the arrow: and I inserted a probe into it, and I removed it: and he was cured, and no misfortune befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man into whose back an arrow had struck, and the wound over it had healed.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years had passed, the arrow emerged from the root of his thigh.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 And I saw a woman into whose belly an arrow had struck, and the wound over it had healed, and the arrow remained within her: and nothing about her condition changed, and the woman found no harm in any of her natural functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 I saw another man who had an arrow fall into his face; the wound became healed and remained, causing him little pain. And there were many similar cases like these.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 I removed an arrow from a man who was one of the King's nobles; it had fallen into his nose and had already deviated slightly to the right side, and the entire arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 Therefore I was called for his treatment after the fall of the arrow until three days later.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 I found that the wound from the arrow was very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 I sought to examine it with a fine probe, but did not feel anything; and he himself felt the puncture and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 Therefore I hoped that the puncture was from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I plastered the place with a plaster that had attracting and digestive power, confident in myself that the spot would swell up and give me a sign of the arrow so that I could cut over it; but nothing happened in the place indicating that the arrow had reached there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 Therefore I continued to plaster it with a plaster for many days; and no sign appeared, but the wound became healed in the meantime. And he remained weak from its extraction for some time until one day he felt the arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I placed a sharp, caustic medicine on that wound for many days until it opened up; and with a fine probe I probed it, and felt the tip of the arrow which was attached to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added to the opening of the wound with that sharp medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared visibly; and for me, a period of about four months had passed with him.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 After the wound had become enlarged and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it and move it, but it did not comply with coming out; then I did not stop seeking ways and contrivances over it until one day I began on it with well-made forceps, as will appear in their form at the end of this chapter, until I removed it. "> Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And indeed physicians judge that the nasal cartilage cannot be restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 Therefore I restored it [the nasal cartilage], and the wound was healed, and the patient was cured with perfect health; nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you the method of extracting certain arrowheads, so that you may take this as a rule and interpretation for what I have not said.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Since the parts of this art and their divisions are not included with the narration; nor does the book contain them, and a skilled craftsman compares what is present to what is absent, and finds a new operation and a new instrument for unusual occurrences in this art when they happen.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I say therefore that arrows do not come out of the members to which they are fixed except in two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Either by pulling from the place through which it entered.  />
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or by cutting through the opposite side of the limb.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which comes out from where it entered is either an arrow proceeding in a fleshy place, and is pulled out, and comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 But if it does not submit to coming out from the hour in which it fell, then you must leave it alone for several days until the flesh surrounding it putrefies; and its removal is relaxed and its exit facilitated.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly, if it is fixed in a bone and does not submit to coming out, then leave it alone also for several days; and continue to pull on it with every movement every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 But if it does not submit to coming out after several days, then you must bore around the arrow in the bone from every side with a fine awl until the arrow is enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then pull on it and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head and has already penetrated one of the cavities of the brain, and some of those symptoms which I mentioned appear in the patient: then abstain from pulling out the arrow, and leave it there until its condition stabilizes after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 For if an arrow reaches the spinal cord, then death is not delayed for that person.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 And if the arrow is not fixed except in the bone itself and does not penetrate to the spinal cord, and the patient remains for some days, and none of those symptoms occur to him: then use skill in extracting the arrow.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 But if it is fixed very firmly and does not yield to extraction: then apply trephines around the arrow, as I have told you: then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 But if the arrow is already hidden in the body and concealed from sense: then seek it with probes.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 But if you feel it, then extract it with certain instruments that are suitable for its extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 But if you cannot reach it because of the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow in depth, and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein there: then enlarge the wound over it, until the wound is widened and it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 But if there are any barbs with which it is held, then free the attached flesh from all sides by every means you can, and use ingenuity, if it cannot be pulled out because of the tearing of the flesh in the fracture and twisting of the bones, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And you, when you administer the extraction of an arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting of your hand with forceps in all parts, until you make it come out: and act subtly at last with great subtlety, so that the arrow is not broken, and the extraction of itself becomes difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot heal it within one hour, then leave it for a few days until what is around it rots.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then revisit it: for the skin will be relieved. But if you experience a flow of blood, then administer what was said about treatment in its chapter: and guard your strength from cutting a vein, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer skill in every way possible for the arrow's escape: and let it be with ease, tranquility, slowness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when you pull the arrow, you make it weak according to the shape as it was at the time of the arrow's entry into the body.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because this is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 But if that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 If the arrow comes out from the opposite side or if something already protrudes to the outside, or if the tip of the arrow causes a swelling that you can feel through the skin above it and you see it protruding, then cut over it, and let the incision be as wide as forceps can grasp.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then pull it out, for it becomes easy to exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 But if it is stuck in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness until the arrow impresses itself into the bone and enlarges its own passage; then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if not: leave it for a few days; then revisit it until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the arrowhead is wooden, then push it through with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 But if the wooden part has broken off and you wish to administer a push: then introduce into it a concave instrument so that its concavity fits into the arrow's shaft; then push it out with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If however the arrowhead is concave, then push it with an entering tool into itself.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 The arrow is relieved by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 And if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out all of the flesh in which there is venom: if you are able to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then treat it with what is appropriate for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 But if the arrow falls into the chest or belly or bladder or side, and it is close to that which you touch with a probe, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut and be careful not to cut a vein or nerve, and extract it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then stitch the wound if you see it and treat it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the shape of forceps with which arrows are extracted.
