Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The ends should be like the beak of a bird, made of iron, and when they grasp onto the arrowhead, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And from them many forms are made: large and small and medium-sized, according to the size and slenderness of the arrow, and the width and depth of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The shape of a concave pusher.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 And the shape of a deaf pusher.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is the end like a radius, so that its entrance into the concave arrowhead may be relieved and pushed with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The end of the concave pusher is concave like a bird's feather, so that the arrowhead’s entrance into it and its thrust may be relieved.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 ¶ On bloodletting of veins.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 There are thirty veins that are commonly used for bloodletting in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 Of which there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins that are behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries that appear in both temples; and two veins that are in both tear ducts of the two eyes, which are called the "watchers"; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein that is at the tip of the nose. />
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And the two jugular veins that are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And the two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And the two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And the two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 But the veins which are bled in the arms are five in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is the cephalic, and it is from the side of the woods; and the common people name it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 And the dark one.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And it is the median vein, and it is composed of a branch of the basilic and a branch of the cephalic; and the common people name it the vein of the body. 》 》 》 》
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And the basilic, and it is placed on the domestic side; and it is also named the tickler.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And the common people name it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And the tendon of the arm, and it is placed on top of the faucet; and that is the one which is bled, and it is that which appears above the thumb in a clear manner.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And the little savior; and it is the vein which is between the ring finger and the smallest one; and there are two branches to it.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 One of them is that which is under the curvature of the thumb on the side of the woods. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 And the second one is the saphenous; and its place is near the heel on the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And the vein called nessis; and its place is by the heel on the side of the woods.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And in the other part of the leg there are three similar veins. 》 》 》 》 》 》 》
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 ¶ On the bleeding of the two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 Cutting the two veins behind the ears is beneficial for old catarrhs, migraines, scabies, and old sores of the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 And the manner of bleeding it is as I relate:
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 And it is done by shaving the head of the patient, and rubbing his occiput where the two veins are with a rough cloth until well rubbed.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then let the patient tie their neck with a band, until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 And their locations are behind the ears, in two depressed areas of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Therefore seek them with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, mark there with a cautery.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take the phlebotomy knife, which is called an incision knife.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then insert it under the vein into the skin, until the phlebotomist reaches the mouth of the vein.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upward, and cut the vein with the skin using an incising cut.  And let the blood flow from the vein until it flows of its own accord.  Then take a cotton bandage and bind the wound well with it, so that no air may reach the wound.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be about the size of two joined fingers, or thereabouts; and let out as much blood as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then bind it with wool bandages, and leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now, at the beginning of this chapter, there was described their incision and cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 ¶ On the bleeding of the two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The bleeding of the two arteries which are in the temples is beneficial for old migraines, crooked squinting, chronic blepharitis, and the flow of sharp excess fluids to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the manner of bleeding them is as I shall tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 The patient should tighten his neck greatly until two veins become clearly visible to the touch and their pulse is felt under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then mark those signs with cautery.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then lift the skin above the vein with your index finger and introduce the lancet underneath it, lifting the vein upwards.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 Cut it as you did with the two other veins, and let the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 Then release the patient's constriction and place your finger over the vein for one hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then place a bandage and some wool over it, and tie it firmly with a constriction: leave it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now, the mention of them, their cutting, and their extraction has preceded at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 § On bleeding the temporal vein after cephalic bloodletting.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 The benefit of bleeding the temporal vein is after cephalic bloodletting for old facial diseases, and for migraine and redness, and foul ulcers. ›
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And its quality of bloodletting is as I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 The patient should constrict his neck with a cord until the vein appears. › ›
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take the instrument called a scoop. › ›
Cuius haec est forma.	 Whose form is this.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Place the pointed tip of the scoop over the vein and strike it with a comb or something similar to it; allow the blood to flow according to your will.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then release the patient's constriction and tie it firmly until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes it is opened with a wide lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However, it should not be a sharp-pointed lancet like the others; rather, it should have a broad point. › › ›
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 And with bloodletting she is according to transfusion, because the mouth is nearby; and perhaps the bloodletter will break there when it is delicate.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 About Bloodletting of Veins at Both Lacrimal Orifices.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 The treatment of the two veins that are in both lacrimal orifices is for the eye due to scabies and redness, and for inflammation in the eye, and diseases of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 And the quality of bloodletting them is that the patient should tie their neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then bleed them, and you should be standing over their head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 And let the bloodletting be along the length of a little, with a small bloodletter, somewhat wide, for there is no flesh in that place. 
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 For if the bloodletter is delicate at the tip, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 Then let as much blood flow out as you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 And place a poultice over them and bind them for one night, and then remove it.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 About Bloodletting of the Veins of the Nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The bloodletting of the veins of the nose is beneficial for acute fever and severe headache, and diseases of the face, such as migraine and redness that occurs on the face; especially when it is chronic.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 And the quality of this bloodletting is that the patient should tie their neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold his nose with your left hand and take a thin, long bloodletter, and insert it into the middle of the nostril itself, between what divides the nose lengthwise. ¨
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 Because the vein is not apparent there by touch, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And it is necessary that you should remove your hand with the bloodletter a little and let as much blood flow out as you need. ¨ ¨ ¨ ¨ ¨ ¨ ¨
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 Then tie it up for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 For it is quickly restored.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 § On the venesection of the veins, according to Guidi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 But Guidi's two venesections are beneficial for treating shortness of breath, the onset of leprosy, melancholic illnesses, impetigo and severe ulcers, and gnawing pains, that is, herpes zoster.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 And the method of these venesections is that the patient should draw tight under both armpits with a ligature; and the practitioner should stand over the patient's head, and the patient should be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 Then make a small incision in the vein to the length of a wide venesection.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then draw out a measured amount of blood, or as much as is necessary for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Then do the same with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Then loosen the ligature and tie both veins tightly in the middle, so that the patient is not suffocated. 
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And leave it like this until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 For the wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 § On the venesection of the veins, according to al-Zahrawi.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 Al-Zahrawi's venesections are beneficial for treating mouth sores and rotten gums, severe ulcers and lip fissures, as well as those in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 And the method of these venesections is that you should make the patient sit before you and bind their neck with a cord.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Then turn the patient's lip inside out and look for the two veins, one of which is on the right side of the lip and the other on the left, and both are distinguishable by their dark color.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 This is true, because around them there are small, black veins.  
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Cut both with intersecting cuts.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 But if you are in doubt and do not know which one it is: then make an incision into the larger and more prominent of the two.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And do the same with the two veins that are in the upper lip; for usually it runs with that one, and make an incision into the two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 On venesection: The vein under the tongue after a venesection of the cephalic vein.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 The venesection of the two veins under the tongue is beneficial because the cephalic venesection is for afflictions of the throat, sore throat, and mouth diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 And the method of venesection is as follows: let the patient sit between your hands facing the sun; lift up his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side for a vein, and on the other side for another vein; and both will be dark in color.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 Venesection them both; and take care not to finish too quickly when venesecting them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 For there are arteries beneath it, and possibly a hemorrhage might occur from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 On the three veins in the elbow. ¶
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are venesected in the elbow run with custom in all people. ¶ ・
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 And their venesection is done in two ways. ・ ・ ・
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Either by pricking with a broad myrtle venesection needle, or with an olive wood needle sharpened to a point, or by cutting with a venesection knife, which is called al-nasil.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form:
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 It is like this, suitable for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And from them are wide and thin varieties according to the width and narrowness of the veins. The form of the myrtle venesection needle should be broad, as you see. ・
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 And it is suitable for opening hollow veins, full, protruding, visible, large, and those which contain thick, cloudy blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 And this phlebotomy is of lesser width and more delicate in its ends.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 And it is suitable for phlebotomy of fine veins that contain fine yellowish blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 About the phlebotomy of the basilic vein.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 However, the basilic is one of these three veins whose phlebotomy is beneficial.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it draws blood from the illnesses that are under the throat and neck, since it follows the chest and abdomen: and it is fitting for the phlebotomist to be careful when phlebotomizing her, because under her there is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If therefore he errs and adds to the puncture of the phlebotomy, he will cut that artery, and a flow of blood will occur.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 Therefore it is necessary not to phlebotomize her with the phlebotomy needle; rather let him cut with a lancet.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the basilic does not appear with a manifest appearance, then it is necessary to divert her and change to another [vein], or seek some branch of her; or in place of her phlebotomy, the vein of the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 For she is manifest, and cut her with the lancet phlebotomy, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If you wish to perform the phlebotomy of that same [vein], then it is necessary before constriction of the arm, so that you touch the place, until you know the place of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 Then mark the place with a cautery, afterwards bind the arm, and cut the vein with a concave incision using the lancet phlebotomy, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And beware that the blow does not fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 When you see, as you tie the bandage, swelling in the place that you marked with a cautery iron, then that swelling is artery swelling: therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood spurt like a boy's urine, and it is thin and red, then know that it comes from the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 Then hasten and place your finger on it for a long time, and then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If the blood is cut off (for often it is cut off), then bind the arm and leave it, and let the patient beware of moving it; and let him be very cautious about it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And he should not move it for several days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 But if the blood does not stop and overcomes you, and there is no medicine at hand, then cut the artery if it appears to you.  /> Et ligabis eam cum digito: et adiunges super ipsum cataplasma, quae est ex pane farinaceo.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For its ends are contracted and the blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or take the bark of a fig tree and grind it; take one half and bind it over the place of the vein with a suitable bandage, along with threads and small pieces of cloth until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 Then if the blood is cut off, that's good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 And if not, then care for it with the same method mentioned before regarding the dust that cuts off the flow of blood; and the cutting off of its blood is not difficult in most cases because of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of binding it from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 On Venesection of the Dark Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 The venesection of the dark vein is beneficial because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body; therefore, because it is composed of a branch of the basilic vein and a branch of the cephalic vein, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 And it is fitting for the phlebotomist that he be above fear of bleeding from her, because under that is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 Therefore if he adds to the puncture of the bloodletting and finds a nerve, it causes numbness in her, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps she does not heal at all.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 And this nerve often appears to the senses.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 But if it is hidden in certain people and is subtle and does not show itself, then you should place your bloodletting where you bleed her, with a section by the Alnesil, and avoid the nerve with all your might.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 But if the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 ¶ Concerning the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 But the benefit of bleeding the cephalic vein is that it draws blood from the head and helps with eye diseases. ↑ Return to text
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 And it is necessary in this vein, if you wish, that you bleed her by pricking with the olive phlebotomy needle or with the myrtle phlebotomy needle, because it is safer than all the other veins, because there is no artery beneath it, nor a nerve. ↑ Return to text
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 However, it is fitting for you during the bloodletting that you avoid with the phlebotomy needle only the head of the biceps, and seek a softer place: and it does not harm her if she is not found on the first blow, but rather it is repeated over her several times with the phlebotomy. ↑ Return to text ↑ Return to text
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 However, perhaps it swells in certain people when she is not found on the first blow, but that swelling does not harm her at all. ↑ Return to text ↑ Return to text
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 ¶ Concerning the usefulness of bloodletting and the precautions that must be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The quality of bloodletting and its effects are what you should consider in order to correct them.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 The first thing you should know is that bloodletting should only be administered for the preservation of health and to maintain its continuance, and as a precaution against the onset of illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 And for bloodletting to be done in one of the three veins located at the elbow: the cephalic, the dark, and the basilic.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 And bloodletting should be done at the beginning of spring on an empty stomach, in summer and autumn also on an empty stomach; but in winter after eating, when there are signs of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 And let bloodletting be done on the first or third day, after three hours have passed since dawn.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 However, bloodletting administered for illnesses does not have a fixed time; rather, it should be done whenever the circumstances and necessity dictate, whether at night or day, and at any hour and season.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 And children should not be bled until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 Nor should a pregnant woman be bled except from the fourth to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 Nor should the elderly, who have already passed sixty years of age, be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 Therefore, when someone wishes to be bled for any reason, it is necessary that they cleanse their bowels before the bloodletting with a gentle enema, if there is a large amount of retained feces; so that during the bloodletting, the veins do not draw in putrid waste from the intestines which can harm the principal organs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 Nor should a patient who is feeling nauseous or intoxicated be bled, nor someone who is hungover, until these conditions are removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 Nor should a patient with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 And bloodletting should be avoided again after suffering from colic, vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sexual activity, labor, exercise, sleeplessness, fasting, and anything else that weakens the body or spirit.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that; if the blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if it is possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 Then let him enter the bath, if nothing prevents him; or he should be exercised in some manner, so that the blood may be refined.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And place his phlebotomy on the chest, around the third hour of the day, as we have said; and strive that his chest be evacuated that day from all evil animal passions, such as constriction, anger, and fear; and from all physical evils, such as labor, pain, excess, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 And he should make present to himself things whose use has become habitual among people because of their fragrance and pleasant smell, such as festivity and similar things, in a quantity suitable for him.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 Then let the phlebotomist sit on a stool that is higher than the stool for bleeding; afterwards he should extend his arm and rub it himself with his hand two or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 Then let him tighten the cord with a strap and wind it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the tightness be moderate, for if the tightness is uneven, or too tight, then it hinders the flow of blood; and if too loose, then it also hinders the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 Then after tying, it is necessary that the person to be bled rub his hands together until the veins swell and become apparent.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 Then let the phlebotomist cleanse the site of bleeding with a small amount of old oil properly.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 Then let him place the index finger of his left hand on the vein itself, a little below the place where he wishes to make the incision, so that the vein does not flee and the blow is steadier.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Because the veins are like a fleeing string during bloodletting; and there is one full of airiness; and when you place a lancet on it, it contracts under the lancet, deceiving the bloodletter, and the lancet does not open the vein; and if it opens it, it is narrow. Therefore, it is necessary that the bloodletter be firm and careful in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 Then he should put down the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If the vein is opened on the first attempt, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then try it again a little below that place, or above it with haste; if the place does not become swollen.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 If it becomes swollen or the patient is frightened, then leave him for a day or two, and let the bandage not be tight.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Perhaps indeed a warm poultice will draw out the swelling.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 He should not enter a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 Then he may repeat the bloodletting, if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 But if the opening is small or the blood runs thinly; and you fear that not as much blood will come out as you wish: then try the lancet again in the same hole, following its straight course, and add a little to your work.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 And do this quickly, before the place becomes swollen; for a swollen place is common in many people during a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If you see that it has already become swollen, then do not try again at all on the same place; for it does not excuse you from anything.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 And put some olive residue on it; because it relieves the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 It is better for this purpose than oil itself and than other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 And similarly use olive residue in all your bloodlettings, where you hinder the flow of blood; and they do this with theriac of alfarach and with sagzenea, when one of them is placed on the spot.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 The blood is refined and dissolved when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If an abscess occurs at the site of venesection, which often happens especially to those who are not bled except on that occasion or if the opening of the vein is small, then hurry and place a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated slightly, over the spot: and tighten it for one hour because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 And you should do that after the blood has exited from the vein itself, at its completion or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If something black or green remains in the spot after a few days, it does not harm; and if you wish, place on it some dissolved aloe or myrrh, or some juice of mint, that is, pennyroyal, or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 And indeed, abscesses and swellings often occur at the site of venesection on the basilic vein.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Therefore place your hand over it; if you find softness upon pressing it, then that swelling is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 Beware of placing on it any of what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 For perhaps blood from the artery will flow from it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 But make a plaster for it with what has an astringent property, so that the spot may harden.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with the rest of the treatment until he is healed.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 And it is necessary to extract from every person a quantity of blood according to his strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And that which appears from the color becoming over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 For if the blood is black, then let it flow out until it becomes red; and likewise if you see that it is thick, then let it flow until it becomes thin; and similarly if it is sharp, let its sharpness be taken away.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 And he who is full-bodied, strong, and needs a bloodletting once a year, should have the phlebotomy performed on the large vein, and let the phlebotomist be on the side: and in one who is weak, it should be the opposite of that.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 And it is appropriate to extract him at intervals, and that the opening should be narrow; and it is better that what is administered in the phlebotomy of the vein should be a transverse cut, not a prick.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood and from cutting the nerve; and it is more praiseworthy and safer than phlebotomy through length and width.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 And he who is accustomed to fainting at the time of phlebotomy should eat before phlebotomy a little bread soaked in pomegranate juice, or if he is warm, let him take a drink: and draw blood from him three times, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 And if he is of a cold temperament, then let him take before phlebotomy bread soaked in mulberry syrup, or in honey-syrup flavored with spices, or in aromatic fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If fainting occurs during phlebotomy, and the cause is the loss of much blood, then let him drink meat water and a thin fragrant syrup: and use aromatic spices with aloes, and anoint his chest with them; and use the other things that we have mentioned in the division in the chapter on fainting from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 But he who wants to draw blood from his arm and loosen his blood a second time, for him whose phlebotomy is because of much evacuation and whose strength is weak, let him loosen the blood little by little according to the amount of strength, over continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 "Whoever wishes to heal their arm and reduce blood on the second [day], and their body is strong: then let them do it after seven hours or nine from their first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 "But whoever wishes to draw blood from their body toward the opposite side of where it is inclined: it should be treated on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 "But in whose body the blood is already heated and sharpened, causing fever to occur: it is necessary that blood be drawn from them once, and a large amount be extracted; and the opening should be enlarged until syncope occurs. After preserving all the conditions of phlebotomy and placing your hand on their pulse along the course of the blood, so that death does not occur in place of syncope.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 "For this often happens when the person drawing the blood is ignorant and careless.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 "And it is not appropriate, when one wishes to heal an arm and draw blood on the second day, after the vein's opening has already closed and blood flow becomes difficult, to press hard on it with force and quickly stretch and bend [the arm].
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 "For that is very harmful; indeed, leave it alone until it is bled the second time.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 "Or remove with the sharpness of the phlebotomy the clotted blood from the vein's opening and place on it some salt dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 "And place on it some of the tyrica al-farukh or sajzeena, and place a gentle pressure on it until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 "But if the vein has already formed an abscess, then leave it alone and do not cover it until the abscess settles.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 "But if necessity compels you to draw blood on the second day and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize above that same place or in another arm with another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 The vein of the arm is bled in place of the Dark and the Palace, when they are not found or hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 And the manner of bleeding it is that the sick person puts his hand in warm water until it reddens and the vein becomes clearly visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then it should be tied above with a moderately tight knot.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Then make the incision crosswise little by little, not widthwise, nor lengthwise; and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be such that it is made over the wrist slightly.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 But if the flow of blood is prevented, then repeatedly put your hand in warm water and let the blood run into the water until you achieve what you need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 However, if it is a summer day, then you may dispense with repeating the hand in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 And indeed the running of the blood into hot water is especially useful in wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 And this vein's bleeding is safer than all other veins, because there is neither a pulsatile vein nor a nerve beneath it. 》
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 However, the bleeding of the little finger on the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 And the manner of its bleeding is that you tie the little finger with a string or your hand after putting it into warm water until the vein swells and becomes very noticeable to touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then make the incision crosswise.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm it at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 And be careful not to finish the bleeding while your hand is still being bled.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 Underneath it are the bare nerves of the fingers, exposed from the flesh. 》 》
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then put your hand back into the warm water and let the blood run into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 For if you do not irrigate it with hot water, the blood clots at the vein's opening and is prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 So when you have extracted the necessary amount of blood, then place oil and salt on the vein so that it does not clot quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And similarly, you should do this with every tied-off branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	 The remedy for bleeding that vein from the left hand is this: since it is beneficial for diseases of the spleen; and similarly do for its bleeding as you did for the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	 The remedy for bleeding the saphenous veins is for diseases of the lower part of the body, such as diseases of the womb and retention of menstrual flow, and kidney disease, and old ulcers of the hips and legs, and similar ailments.  />
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	 And the procedure for bleeding that vein is as follows: let the patient put his foot into hot water and rub it until the veins swell; then tie above the ankle with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	 And indeed, the place of that vein is at the heel, visible toward the thumb; and many branches spread out from it on the surface of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	 Therefore bleed it either in its larger branch or at the heel where it joins; for this is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	 But if you bleed it on the surface of the foot, then beware of the nerves that are beneath it on the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	 And place your bleeding wound where you want to bleed it from the side, as if you wanted to cut it; and let the size of the incision be a Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	 But if the flow of blood is blocked, then immerse his foot in hot water and allow the blood to flow into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	 If the bloodletter errs in the first attempt and pierces a vein, he should repeat the phlebotomy slightly higher up, for the place is safe, and you need not fear any harm if you avoid the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	 And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot evenly.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The place for the sciatic vein, as we have said, is by the heel on the outer side of the foot.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	 And the benefit of phlebotomy from it is for pain in the ankle when due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	 And the method of phlebotomy from it is that the patient should enter a bath and be in a hurry; and bind the leg from the side of the ankle up to above the heel with four fingers' width, using a fine long bandage, for it does not appear except for this reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	 When it appears, then phlebotomize it by whatever method is possible for you, or by transfusion; and it is better to cut it with a cut or to divide it with a division.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	 For its place is safer, and the vein itself is very hidden in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	 If you do not find it and it does not appear to the touch at all: then phlebotomize one of its branches, which is that one visible on the back of the foot, towards the little toe; and beware of the nerves, and let as much blood flow as you like.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	 Then loosen the bandage, and place a piece of skin over the site of the phlebotomy, and bind the site.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	 For it heals quickly.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	 ¶ On Cupping and its Usefulness
Caput XCVIII.	 Chapter 98
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	 Cups are made from horn, from metal, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	 And cupping is done in two ways. ■
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	 "With scarification and bloodletting: another method is cupping without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	 "And this cupping that is without scarification is performed in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	 "Either it is with fire,
Aut est absque igne.	 "Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	 "And cuppings that are administered with scarification and bloodletting are in fourteen places of the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	 "One of these is the cupping of Alnocrati, which is at the back of the head; and Alkehel, which is in the middle of the neck; and the cuppings of Alhagdahim, which are two flat parts of the neck on both sides together; and the cuppings of the chin, which are under the jawbone on the lower part of the mouth; and the cuppings of the two ribs; and the cuppings of Alachosos, which are at the end of the tail; and the cuppings of the two loins, which are in the middle of the two arms; and the cuppings of the two thighs; and the cuppings of the two calves.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	 "And cupping, indeed, does not extract blood from the small dispersed veins in the flesh; and for this reason, it does not cause weakness as in phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	 "Nor should cupping be administered, whether with fire or without, for any disease that results from fullness until the entire body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	 "But if necessity requires cupping due to illness or habit, we administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in its middle, and at whatever time it may be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	 "That is because there are people who, when their blood increases and they need to extract it through cupping, find heaviness and dizziness in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	 "And among them are those who find fullness and redness in their face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	 And among them is one who finds itching on his face and forehead, and darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	 And among them is one who scratches the place of his farting.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	 And among them is one whose laughter is increased.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	 And among them is one who finds the taste of blood in his mouth; or the tongue swells up and he spits out blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	 And among them is one whose sleep is increased.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	 And among them is one who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and the slain, and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	 When therefore we see something of these things, and especially if it is in the third week of the month: then we order that a purging be done after two or three hours have passed from the day.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	 But the relief of purging the neck is: because it contributes to heaviness in the head and what flows out into the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	 And indeed it is necessary that this be after the evacuation of the whole body. 》
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	 And this purging takes the place of a phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	 And it is not permissible for one who has a cold temperament or who has catarrh to use it. 》
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	 For it brings him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	 And because of this, it is not right that old people and those who have cold illnesses in the head should use them.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	 But he who becomes habituated to it generates forgetfulness upon himself.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	 And because of this, it is necessary to order the purger that he lower his hand with the purging slightly downward, fearing from the cause of forgetfulness. 》 》
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	 The purging called Alkehel is in place of a dark phlebotomy and a basilica phlebotomy, and because of this it helps with asthma, constriction of breath, cleft palate, coughing, and fullness.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	 And it is necessary that a cupping glass be applied briefly to al-Khayl, because if it is placed lower, it causes weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	 However, cupping the al-Hadhim area is effective for headaches, migraines, and toothache; it is an alternative to basal phlebotomy.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And you should instruct the cupper not to press his hand on the skin after scarifying, lest he cut an artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	 Cupping under the chin is effective for mouth ulcers and gum disease, as well as similar oral ailments; it serves as an alternative to phlebotomy of the lip corners.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	 Cupping with a spoon is effective for al-Khaffakh, which is caused by indigestion and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	 Cupping the inner parts of the two groins is as beneficial as phlebotomy of the three veins, the basilic, cephalic, and median cubital; for it draws blood from all the small veins in the flesh, which in turn draw from larger veins, until the drawing reaches the three main veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	 And you should instruct the cupper not to cut too deeply when scarifying, since the area is bare of flesh and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	 A cupping glass placed over the anus is effective for hemorrhoids and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	 And you should instruct the cupper to use a large cupping glass made of brass, since the area requires strong suction and fine glasses might break; he should also make a deep cut.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	 Cupping the legs reduces swelling visibly, since it draws blood from the entire body; it relieves old pains in the kidneys, bladder, and uterus, stimulates menstruation, and improves complexion and appetite. It serves as an alternative to phlebotomy of both saphenous veins and the great metatarsal vein. )))
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	 Indeed, they greatly weaken the body and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	 And the remedy for Ventosarum of the leg is similar to the remedy for Ventosarum of two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	 The method for applying the Ventosa is as follows: first place the cup on an empty area and apply moderate suction. Do not prolong the position of the cup, but rather place and remove it quickly so that the humors may arrive at the site equally. Continue this process without interruption until you see the site become red and swollen, and the blood appear. At that point, make an incision, and then continue with gradual suction.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	 Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	 For those who have tender flesh and few pores, you should incise once only, no more, so that the site does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	 And instruct the person applying the cups to widen the incision slightly and make it deep enough; they should regulate the suction so that it is gentle, quick, and smooth in motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	 If there is thickening of the blood, then you should incise twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	 With the first incision, the way is opened for the thinning and watering down of the blood; with the second, it is subjected to a thorough examination of the thick blood’s extraction.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	 If, however, the blood is extremely dirty, then a third incision should be made so that it may reach its final state.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	 And in the end, when we want to extract the blood little by little or briefly, one incision is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	 If we wish to make many extractions of blood, we should use many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	 And if we measure and find that the blood is thick, then it should be incised with a deep incision; and the equal limit of the incision’s depth is the thickness of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	 What is that which must be applied from the oils at the site of the Ventosa, and what should the one applying the Ventosa beware of?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	 IN the case of one whose skin is thick, hard, dark, and whose pores are narrow, it is necessary that the places to be ventosed be anointed with openings, softening, and dissolving oils: if it is in summertime, such as alkeiri oil, or violet oil, or oil of sweet almonds, or oil of cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	 And if it is in wintertime, then narcissus oil, or lily oil, or chamomile oil, or savory oil: and similar ones to these.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	 But if the excess is thick and cold, then it should be bitter orange oil, or balm oil, or alben oil, or dill oil: and similar ones to these.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	 But if the one to be ventosed has large pores and soft flesh, then it is necessary that he be kept from oil, and it is necessary that these wash the places to be ventosed with rose water, or cold water, or saltwater, or cucumber water, or purslane water: and similar ones to these. 》
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	 But that one whose blood is very moist, should wash the ventosae with vinegar, or myrtle water, and sumac water: and similar ones to these.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	 But that one whose excesses are thick, should wash his ventosae with old wine, or sage water, or dill decoction, or chamomile: and similar ones to these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	 And it is necessary that the ventosa be applied not in a bath or after a bath; indeed, it should be administered after an hour or two hours have passed since leaving the bath.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	 And it is not appropriate for anyone to sleep after ventilation.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	 What should be done to ensure that the patient who needs to be ventilated or bled is properly prepared before ventilation?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	 And after that you should consider first of all: whether the patient who has been ventilated or bled is choleric and if sharpness and inflammation prevail in their blood, then they should receive cooling substances such as pomegranate seeds, and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and cucumbers, and jujubes, and similar things. ¶
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	 And make his food soft, and give him cooked mutton, and foods prepared with sour sauce, and similar things.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	 And if the patient's complexion is cold, it is appropriate for them to take in drink syrup of honey or of almond, and a dessert of seeds; and let them take medium-aged wine that is between old and new; and they should be advised to use little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	 And make his food soft, and let him have quails and small birds, and young pigeons is good for him.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	 And it is appropriate that on the day of ventilation and bloodletting, drink should be more than food; and it is appropriate that in some people's drink, there should be given theriac alfaroch or a medicine from musk, that is muscat, or alesselithe before ventilation: and before bloodletting, or after: so that the principal members may be strengthened, and the blood may be refined.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	 And it is not appropriate for them to take it in hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	 About ventosas without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	 But the ventosas which are without scarification are those which are placed on the liver and spleen, and on gout, and on the abdomen, and the navel, and on the places of the kidneys, and on the bladder; because these members do not tolerate scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	 And it is not sought through them except either by contact of blood from one member to another, as we place Ventose on the breasts in the disease of nasal blood flow.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	 And we use them to dissolve from the member cold and unseen windiness in the member, as we place Ventose on the belly and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	 For she indeed rarefies the member and heats it and removes the pain for this reason: because she dissolves that windiness.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	 It is also placed on the kidneys when an obstruction or stone occurs there.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	 For perhaps by the power of its attraction it opens the obstruction or removes the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	 And similarly when it is placed on the liver and spleen for grinding windiness in both of them.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	 And these Ventose are applied empty only with a cut.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	 And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	 And sometimes they are administered full of warm water in diseases of pleurisy: and this is done so that the Ventose may be filled with great hot water alone or with water in which appropriate herbs have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	 ¶ The form of the Ventose applied with fire. ¶
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	 Let its opening be two fingers wide as we have shaped it: and let its depth be half a palm: and let there be on one of its sides, in the middle part, a small hole the size that can admit an awl: make it from copper or brass, thick-rimmed, smooth, equal, polished so that it does not harm the member upon which it is placed. And let there be in its center a transverse rod of copper or iron where a candle with fire is placed.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	 And now this Ventose is made large, larger than we have described and somewhat smaller than that one, according to the disease and age of the person using it. ¶
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	 The swellings of boys and emaciated persons are different from those of men and robust bodies.
